div0.head: Φ

div1.head: φαάντατος
div1.sense: brightest, Od.

div1.head: φαάντερος
div1.sense: brighter, Anth.

div1.head: φαγεῖν
div1.etym: no pres. in use, used as aor2 of ἐσθίω
div1.sense: to eat, devour, φαγέμεν καὶ πιέμεν Od.; φαγεῖν τε καὶ πιεῖν Ar., etc.; c. gen. to eat of a thing, Od.
to eat up, devour, squander, Od.
in NTest. occurs a fut. φάγομαι, 2nd sg. φάγεσαι.

div1.head: φάγος
div1.sense: a glutton, NTest.

div1.head: φαεθοντίς
div1.sense: shining, Anth.

div1.head: φαέθω
div1.sense: to shine, only found in part. φαέθων, beaming, radiant, Hom., Soph., Eur.; absol., πάννυχα καὶ φαέθοντα nights and days, Soph.
as a prop. n.
φαέθων, ὁ, shiner, one of the steeds of Eos, Od.
son of Helios or Apollo, famous for his unlucky driving of the sun-chariot, Eur.
the planet Jupiter, Cic.

div1.head: φαεινός
div1.note: φαεινός, Doric and Attic φαεννόσος, η, ον
div1.sense: shining, beaming, radiant, Hom., Pind., Trag.
of the voice, clear, distinct, far-sounding, Pind.
generally, splendid, brilliant, Pind.

div1.head: φαεσίμβροτος
div1.sense: bringing light to mortals, Hom., Eur.

div1.head: φαεσφόρος
div1.sense: light-bringing, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: Φαίαξ
div1.sense: Ionic Φαίηξ, ηκος, a Phaeacian: they were the Homeric inhabitants of the island of Scheria (i. e. Corcyra, now Corfu), Od.

div1.head: φαίδιμος
div1.sense: shining, of menʼs limbs, prob. in reference to the common use of oil, Od., Hes., Pind.
of heroes, famous, glorious, Hom., Aesch.

div1.head: φαιδρόνους
div1.sense: with bright, joyous mind, Aesch.

div1.head: φαιδρόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to beam with joy, Xen.

div1.head: φαιδρός
div1.sense: bright, beaming, Aesch.: sparkling, of water, Anth.
metaph. beaming with joy, bright, joyous, jocund, Solon., Trag., Xen.:—adv. -δρῶς, joyously, cheerily, Xen.; neut. pl. φαιδρά as adv., Soph.

div1.head: φαιδρότης
div1.sense: brightness: joyousness, Isocr.

div1.head: φαιδρυντής
div1.sense: a cleanser, washer:—fem. φαιδρύντρια, Aesch.

div1.head: φαιδρύνω
div1.sense: to make bright, to cleanse, Aesch.; θεαὶ μορφὰν ἐφαίδρυναν gave me a bright form, Eur.: —in Mid., χρόα φαιδρύνεσθαι to wash oneʼs skin clean, Hes.
metaph. to cheer, Aesch.:—Pass. to beam or brighten up with joy, Xen.

div1.head: φαιδρωπός
div1.sense: with bright, joyous look, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: φαικάς
div1.sense: a white shoe, Anth.

div1.head: φαινόλης
div1.sense: formed from the Lat. paenula, a thick upper garment, a cloak, NTest.

div1.head: φαινόλις
div1.sense: light-bringing, Hhymn.

div1.head: Φαίνων
div1.sense: a planet, shiner, our Saturn, Cic.

div1.head: φαίνω
div1.sense: Act. to bring to light, make to appear, Hom., etc.:—Mid. to exhibit as oneʼs own, Soph.
to shew forth, make known, reveal, disclose, shew, Od., Soph. etc.: γόνον Ἑλένηι φ. to shew her a child, i. e. grant her to bear one, Od.
of sound, to make it clear to the ear, make it ring clear, Od., Aesch.
to make clear, explain, expound, Hdt.
in Attic to inform against one, to indict, impeach, Ar.:— to inform of a thing as contraband, Ar.: Pass., τὰ φανθέντα articles informed against as contraband, Dem.
absol. to give information, Xen.
φαίνειν φρουράν at Sparta, to proclaim a levy, call out the array, Xen.
absol. to give light, Od.; so of the sun, moon, etc., φ. τινί Ar., Theocr.; so of the Dioscuri shining in mid-air, Eur.; ἀγανὴ φαίνουσʼ ἐλπίς soft shining hope, Aesch.
Hom. uses the Ionic aor. φάνεσκε really intr., appeared:— also perf. 2 πέφηνα is intr., Hdt., Soph., Dem.
Pass. to come to light, be seen, appear, Hom.; of fire, to shine brightly, Hom.:—often of the rising of heavenly bodies, Il., Hes.; of daybreak, φάνη ῥοδοδάκτυλος Ἠώς Hom.

of persons, to come into being, φανεὶς δύστηνος born to misery, Soph.; δοῦλος φανείς shewn to be, having become, a slave, Soph.:—also of events, τέλος πέφανται Il.; τὸ φανθέν what has once come to light, Soph., etc.

to appear to be so and so, c. inf., ἥτις ἀρίστη φαίνεται εἶναι Od.; τοῦτό μοι θειότατον φαίνεται γενέσθαι Hdt.:—inf. omitted, ὅστις φαίνηται ἄριστος Od., etc.:—also c. part., but φαίνεσθαι c. inf. indicates that a thing appears to be so and so, φαίνεσθαι c. part. states the fact that it manifestly is so and so, ἐμοὶ σὺ πλουτέειν φαίνεαι you appear to me to be rich, Hdt.; but, εὔνοος ἐφαίνετο ἐών he was manifestly well-inclined, Hdt.; φαίνεται ὁ νόμος βλάπτων the law manifestly harms, but, φαίνεται ὁ νόμος ἡμᾶς βλάψειν it appears likely to harm us, Dem.:—with the part. omitted, Κᾶρες ἐφάνησαν (sc. ὄντες) they were manifest Carians, Thuc.; τί φαίνομαι (sc. ὤν); what do I look like? Eur.
in dialogue, φαίνεταί σοι ταῦτα; does this appear so? is not this so? Answ. φαίνεται, yes, Plat.; [τοῦτο φῆις εἶναι; Answ. φαίνομαι (sc. λέγειν) Xen.
οὐδαμοῦ φανῆναι nullo in loco haberi, Plat.

div1.head: φαιός
div1.sense: dusky, dun, gray, Lat. fuscus, Plat.

div1.head: φαιοχίτων
div1.sense: dark-robed, Aesch.
div1.etym: second syll. long, quasi φαιοκχίτων; v. X χ fin.

div1.head: φάκελος
div1.sense: a bundle, fagot, Lat. fasciculus, Hdt., Eur.; ὕλης φάκελοι fascines, Thuc.

div1.head: φακῆ
div1.sense: a dish of lentils (φακοί) , lentil-soup, Ar.

div1.head: φακός
div1.sense: lentil, and its fruit, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: φαλαγγηδόν
div1.sense: in phalanxes, Il., Polyb.

div1.head: φαλαγγομαχέω
div1.sense: to fight in a phalanx; generally, to fight in the ranks, Xen.

div1.head: φαλαγγομάχης
div1.sense: one who fights in the phalanx, Anth.

div1.head: φάλαγξ
div1.sense: a line of battle, battle-array, Il.; mostly in pl. the ranks, Il., Hes.

the phalanx, i. e. the heavy infantry (ὁπλῖται) in battle-order, Xen., etc.: the formation of the phalanx differed; the Spartan line at Tegea was eight deep, Thuc.: the Theban at Delium twenty-five, Thuc.; the phalanx was brought to perfection by Philip of Macedon.
for the main body, centre, as opp. to the wings (κέρατα) , Xen.
a camp, Xen.
a round piece of wood, a trunk, log, Hdt.
a venomous spider (cf. φαλάγγιον) , Ar.

div1.head: φαλακρόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to become bald, Hdt.

div1.head: φαλακρός
div1.sense: baldheaded, bald, Hdt., Plat., etc.; πρόσωπον φαλακρόν Eur.

div1.head: φάλανθος
div1.sense: bald in front, Anth.

div1.head: φαλαντίας
div1.sense: a bald man, Luc.

div1.head: φάλαρα
div1.sense: bosses on the sides of the helmet, to which the chin-straps were attached, Il.: —the sg., φάλαρον τιάρας, part of the headdress of the old Persian kings, Aesch.
bosses or discs of metal, used to adorn the head-gear of horses, Lat. phalerae, Hdt., Soph., etc.

div1.head: φαλαρίς
div1.sense: the coot, so called from its bald white head, Ar.

div1.head: φάλαρος
div1.sense: having a patch of white, ὁ κύων ὁ φάλαρος the dog with a white spot, Theocr.

div1.head: Φαληρεύς
div1.sense: a Phalerian, Hdt.

div1.head: φαληριάω
div1.sense: to be patched with white, κύματα φαληριόωντα waves crested with white foam, Il.

div1.head: Φαληρικός
div1.sense: of or from Phalerum, Ar.

div1.head: Φαληρόθεν
div1.sense: from Phalerum, Plat.

div1.head: Φαληροῖ
div1.sense: at Phalerum, Xen.

div1.head: Φαληρόνδε
div1.sense: to Phalerum, Thuc.

div1.head: Φάληρον
div1.sense: Phalerum, the western harbour of Athens

div1.head: φαλῆς
div1.sense: Phales, associated with the worship of Bacchus, Ar.

div1.head: φάλλαινα
div1.sense: a whale, Lat. ba_laena, Babr.:—hence of any monster, Lat. bellua, Ar.

div1.head: φαλλικός
div1.sense: of or for the φαλλός:—τὸ φαλλικόν (sc. μέλος) the phallic song, Ar.

div1.head: φαλλός
div1.sense: membrum virile, phallus, a figure borne in procession in the Bacchic orgies, as an emblem of the generative power in nature, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: φάλος
div1.sense: a part of the helmet worn by the Homeric heroes, either a metal ridge in which the plume (λόφος) was fixed, or (rather) the peak of the helmet: then, an ἀμφίφαλος κυνέη would be one that had a peak behind as well as before.

div1.head: φαναῖος
div1.sense: giving or bringing light, Eur.

div1.head: φανερόμισος
div1.sense: openly hating, Arist.

div1.head: φανερός
div1.sense: open to sight, visible, manifest, evident, Hdt., Attic:— φανερός εἰμι, c. part., φανεροί εἰσι ἀπικόμενοι they are known to have come, Hdt.; so, φανεροὶ γιγνόμενοι ὅτι ποιοῦσιν Xen.
open, of a road, Hdt.
φ. οὐσία real property, opp. to money (ἀφανής 6), Dem., etc.
of votes, φ. ψήφῳ by open vote, opp. to κρύβδην (ballot), Thuc., etc.

adv. -ρῶς, openly, manifestly, Hdt., Attic: comp. φανερώτερον Thuc.:— τὸ φανερόν is often joined with Preps. in adverb. sense, ἐκ τοῦ φανεροῦ openly, Hdt., etc.; so, ἐν τῷ φανερῷ Xen.; ἐστὸ φανερόν Thuc.
of gods, known, acknowledged, Hdt.; of persons, conspicuous, Soph., Thuc.

div1.head: φανερόφιλος
div1.sense: openly loving, an open friend, Arist.

div1.head: φανερόω
div1.sense: to make manifest, NTest.
to make known or famous:—Pass. to become so, Hdt.

div1.head: φανή
div1.sense: a torch:—a torch-procession, such as took place in the Bacchic orgies, Eur.

div1.head: φανός
div1.sense: light, bright, Xen.:— τὸ φανόν brightness, light, Plat.
of garments, washed clean, Ar.
metaph. bright, joyous, Aesch., Plat.
conspicuous, Plat.
adv. -νῶς perspicuously; Sup. φανότατα, Luc.

div1.head: φανός2
div1.sense: a torch of vine-twigs, Xen.; cf. πᾱνός.,

div1.head: φαντάζω
div1.sense: to become visible, appear, shew oneself, Hdt., Eur.
to make a show, exalt oneself, Lat. se ostentare, Hdt.
φαντάζεσθαί τινι to make oneself like some one, Aesch.
in Ar., = συκοφαντεῖσθαι, to be informed against.

div1.head: φαντασία
div1.sense: imagination, the power by which an object is presented (φαίνεται) to the mind (the object presented being φάντασμα) , Plat., Arist.

div1.head: φάντασμα
div1.sense: an appearance, phantasm, phantom, Aesch., Eur.:— a vision, dream, Theocr.
in Philosophy, v. φαντασία.
a mere image, unreality, Plat.

div1.head: φάος
div1.etym: Epic nom. and acc. pl. φάεα [ᾱ metri grat.]
div1.sense: light, daylight, Hom., etc.:—in Poets, of life, ζώειν καὶ ὁρᾶν φάος ἠελίοιο Hom.; λείπειν φάος ἠελίοιο Hes.; πέμπειν τινὰ ἐς φῶς Aesch.; πρὸς φῶς ἀνελθεῖν Soph.
of day-light, ἐν φάει Od.; φῶς γίγνεται it is becoming light, i. e. day is breaking, Plat.; ἕως ἔτι φῶς ἐστι while there is still light, Plat.
the light of a torch, lamp, fire, a light, Od., Aesch.
the light of the eyes, Pind.; pl. φάεα the eyes, Lat. lumina, Od.
light, as a metaph. for deliverance, happiness, victory, Il.: also in addressing persons, γλυκερὸν φάος dear light of my life, Od.; ὦ φίλτατον φῶς Soph.

div1.head: φάραγξ
div1.sense: a cleft or chasm in a mountain, a ravine, gully, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: φαρέτρα
div1.sense: a quiver for arrows, Lat. pharetra, Hom.

div1.head: Φαρισαῖος
div1.sense: a Pharisee, Separatist (from pharash, to distinguish), one of a sect who separated themselves from other Jews as affecting superior holiness.

div1.head: φαρμακάω
div1.sense: to suffer from the effect of poison, to be ill or distraught, Dem.

div1.head: φαρμακεία
div1.sense: the use of drugs, potions, spells, Plat.
poisoning, witchcraft, Lat. veneficium, Dem.
remedy, cure, Arist.

div1.head: φαρμακεύς
div1.sense: a poisoner, sorcerer, Soph.

div1.head: φαρμακεύω
div1.sense: to administer a drug, Plat.
to use enchantments, φαρμακεύειν τι ἐς τὸν ποταμόν to use it as a charm to calm the river, Hdt.
c. acc. pers. to drug, give him a poisonous or stupefying drug, Eur.

div1.head: φαρμακίς
div1.sense: a sorceress, witch, Lat. venefica, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: φάρμακον
div1.sense: a drug, medicine, Hom., etc.: the φάρμακα applied outwardly were χριστά, ἔγχριστα, ἐπίχριστα (ointments), and παστά, ἐπίπαστα, καταπλαστά (plasters), Theocr., Ar.; those taken inwardly βρώσιμα, and πότιμα, ποτά, πιστά, Aesch., Eur., etc.:—c. gen., φ. νόσου a medicine for it, remedy against it, Aesch.; φ. κεφαλῆς for a head-ache, Plat.
in bad sense, an enchanted potion, philtre, so a charm, spell, enchantment, Od., Theocr.:—also a drug, poison, Soph., Eur.
a remedy, cure, Hes.; φ. πραΰ, of a bridle, Pind.; c. gen. a remedy against, βλάβης Aesch.; πόνων, λύπης Eur.
c. gen., also, a means of producing, σωτηρίας Eur.; σοφίας Plat.
a dye, paint, colour, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: φαρμακοποσία
div1.sense: a drinking of medicine, Xen., Plat.
a drinking of poison, Luc.

div1.head: φαρμακοπώλης
div1.sense: a dealer in drugs, Ar.

div1.head: φαρμακός
div1.sense: a poisoner, sorcerer, magician, NTest.
one who is sacrificed as an atonement for others, a scape-goat, Ar.; and, since worthless fellows were reserved for this fate, φαρμακός became a general name of reproach, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: φαρμακοτρίβης
div1.sense: one who grinds drugs or colours, Dem.

div1.head: φαρμακόω
div1.sense: to endue with healing power, Pind.

div1.head: φαρμακώδης
div1.sense: of the nature of a φάρμακον, medicinal, Arist.
poisonous, Plut.

div1.head: φαρμάσσω
div1.sense: to treat by using φάρμακα, of a metal-worker, who hardens iron by plunging it in water, Od.
to heal or relieve by medicine, Plat.
to bewitch by potions or philtres: hence to bewitch by flattery, Plat.: metaph. in Pass. of a lamp, as φαρμασσομένη χρίματος παρηγορίαις Aesch.

div1.head: Φάρος
div1.sense: Pharos, an island in the bay of Alexandria, Od., Thuc., etc.; famous for its lighthouse, Strab.: then, as appell., φάρος, a lighthouse, Anth.

div1.head: φᾶρος
div1.sense: a large piece of cloth, a web, Hom., Eur.
like χλαῖνα, a cloak or mantle, worn over the χιτών, Hom., etc.:—used as a shroud or pall, Hom., Soph.; also as a coverlet, Soph.

div1.head: φάρσος
div1.sense: a part, portion, φάρσεα πόλιος the quarters of a city, Hdt.

div1.head: φάρυγξ
div1.sense: the throat, gullet, Od., Eur., etc.

div1.head: φάσγανον
div1.sense: a sword, Hom., Soph.

div1.head: φασγανουργός
div1.sense: forging swords, Aesch.

div1.head: φάσηλος
div1.sense: a sort of bean, Ar.
hence Lat. phas[e]lus, a light boat, skiff, from its likeness in shape to a bean-pod, Catull., Hor.

div1.head: Φασιανός
div1.sense: from the river Phasis (v. Φᾶσις) :—ὁ Φ. (sc. ὄρνις) , the Phasian bird, pheasant, Ar.:—so Φασιανικὸς, ὄρνις, with a play on συκοφάντης, Ar.

div1.head: φάσις
div1.sense: an accusation, Dem.

div1.head: φάσις2
div1.sense: an assertion, Arist.

div1.head: Φᾶσις
div1.sense: the river Phasis in Colchis, being the boundary of Europe and Asia, Hes., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: φάσκω
div1.etym: used as imperf. of φημί. the inf. and part. pres. of φημί are also supplied by φάσκω: besides this we find Attic, imperat. φάσκε
div1.sense: to say, affirm, assert, often with a notion of alleging or pretending, Od., Hdt., Attic; ὡς ἔφασκεν as he said, as he alleged, Soph.
to think, deem, expect, Hom., Soph.
to promise, c. inf. fut., Od., Thuc.

div1.head: φάσμα
div1.sense: an apparition, phantom, Hdt., Aesch., etc.; φ. ἀνδρός the spectral appearance of a man, Hdt.:— a vision in a dream, Aesch., etc.
a sign from heaven, portent, omen, Hdt., Trag.
a monster, prodigy, Hdt.; periphr., φάσμα ταύρου a monster of a bull, Soph.

div1.head: φάσσα
div1.sense: a wild pigeon, ringdove, Ar.

div1.head: φασσοφόνος
div1.sense: dove-killing, Il.

div1.head: φατειός
div1.sense: οὔτι φατειός un- utterable, un- speakable, Hes.

div1.head: φατέος
div1.sense: one must say, Plat.

div1.head: φατίζω
div1.sense: to say, speak, report, ἐφάτισαν τὰ γράμματα Φοινικήια κεκλῆσθαι they spoke of them by the name of Phoenician, Hdt.:—Pass., τὸ φατιζόμενον as the saying is, Soph.
to promise, engage, betroth, τὴν παῖδά τινι Eur.:— Pass., ἐμὴ φατισθεῖσα my promised bride, Eur.

div1.head: φάτις
div1.sense: like φήμη, a voice from heaven, the voice of an oracle, an oracle, Aesch., Soph.

a saying among men, common talk, rumour, report, Lat. fama, Od., Trag.; κατὰ φάτιν as report goes, Hdt.; ὡς φ. κρατεῖ Aesch.; ὥσπερ ἡ φ. Soph.; φ. ἐστί ʼtis said that . . , Pind.; ἡ φ. μιν ἔχει the report goes of him, Hdt.
the subject of a saying, a theme, Pind.
speech, words, of a single person, Soph.: speech, language, Aesch.

div1.head: φάτνη
div1.sense: a manger, crib, feeding-trough, Hom., Hdt., Attic

div1.head: φατός
div1.sense: that may be spoken, οὐ φατός un- speakable, un- utterable, in- effable, Hes., Pind.
metaph. named, famous, notable, Hes.

div1.head: φαυλεπίφαυλος
div1.sense: bad upon bad, bad as bad can be, Anth.

div1.head: φαυλίζω
div1.sense: to hold cheap, to depreciate, disparage, Xen.

div1.head: φαῦλος
div1.sense: of things, easy, slight, Eur., Ar., etc.: adv., φαύλως κρίνειν to estimate lightly, Aesch.; φ. ἀποδιδράσκειν to get off easily, Ar.; Sup., φαυλότατα καὶ ῥᾷστα Ar.
trivial, paltry, petty, sorry, poor, Thuc., etc.; φαῦλα ἐπιφέρειν to bring paltry charges, Hdt.: adv., οὔτι φαύλως with no trivial force, Eur.

of persons, low in rank, mean, common, οἱ φαυλότατοι the commonest sort (of soldiers), Thuc., etc.: also in point of education opp. to σοφός, Eur., etc.; c. inf., φαῦλος μάχεσθαι Eur.; φ. λέγειν Plat.
careless, thoughtless, indifferent, Lat. securus, Eur.;—adv., φαύλως εὕδειν Eur.; φ. λογίσασθαι to estimate off-hand, roughly, Ar.; φ. εἰπεῖν, Lat. strictim dicere, carelessly, roughly, Plat.
in good sense, simple, unaffected, Plat.: adv., φαύλως παιδεύειν τινα Xen.

div1.head: φαυλότης
div1.sense: meanness, paltriness, pettiness, badness, of persons and things, Xen., etc.; ἡ φ. τῶν στρατηγῶν their want of skill, Dem.; lack of judgment, Xen.
in good sense, plainness, simplicity, Xen.

div1.head: φάω
div1.sense: to give light, shine (like φαίνω II), Od.

div1.head: φέβομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be put to flight, flee affrighted, Hom.

div1.head: φέγγος
div1.sense: light, splendour, lustre, Hhymn., Pind., Trag.; esp. like φάος, φῶς, daylight, Trag.; δεκάτῳ φέγγει ἔτους in the tenth yearʼs light, i. e. in the tenth year, Aesch.:—also moonlight, Xen.
of men, φ. ἰδεῖν to see the light, come into the world, Pind.; λιπεῖν φ. Eur.
the light of torches or fire, Aesch.:— a light, torch, Ar.; pl. φέγγη watchfires, Plut.
the light of the eyes, Eur., Theocr.; τυφλὸν φ., i. e. blindness, Eur.
light, as a metaph. for glory, pride, joy, Pind., Aesch., etc.

div1.head: φέγγω
div1.sense: to make bright:—Pass. to shine, gleam, Ar.

div1.head: φείδομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to spare, Lat. parcere:
to spare persons and things in war, i. e. not destroy them, c. gen., Hom., Attic:—absol. to spare, be merciful, Thuc.

to spare in using, to refrain from using, use sparingly, ἵππων φειδόμενος, i. e. taking care of them, Il.; μὴ φείδεο σίτου Hes.; φείδεο τῶν νηῶν Hdt.; τι φειδόμεσθα τῶν λίθων; why refrain from using them? Ar.; φ. μήτε χρημάτων μήτε πόνων Plat.
absol. to be sparing, be thrifty, live thriftily, Theogn.; οἱ γεωργοῦντες καὶ φειδόμενος Dem.:—this part is used as adj. = φειδωλός, Ar.:— adv. φειδομένως sparingly, NTest., Plut.
to draw back from, τοῦ κινδύνου Xen.; φείδου μηδὲν ὧνπερ ἐννοεῖς shrink not at all from that thou hast in mind, Soph.:—also c. inf. to spare or cease to do, forbear from doing, Eur.

div1.head: φειδωλός
div1.sense: sparing, thrifty, and as Subst. a niggard, miser, Ar., Plat.; φ. γλῶσσα a niggard tongue, Hes.:—c. gen., φ. χρημάτων Plat.; τὸ φειδωλόν φειδώ, Plat.:—adv. -λῶς, Plat.

div1.head: φείδων
div1.sense: an oil-can with a narrow neck, that lets only a little run out, Theophr.
as pr. n. Φείδων, name of an old man in Com. Poets, Thrifty: — hence patron. Φειδωνίδης, ου, ὁ, Thrifty-son, Ar.

div1.head: φειδώ
div1.sense: a sparing, νεκύων Il.
absol. thrift, parsimony, Od., Hes.: thrift in exposing oneself to danger, Thuc.

div1.head: φειστέος
div1.sense: one must spare, Isocr.

div1.head: φελλεύς
div1.sense: stony ground: as pr. n., Ar.

div1.head: φέλλινος
div1.sense: made of cork, Luc.

div1.head: φελλόπους
div1.sense: cork-footed, Luc.

div1.head: φελλός
div1.sense: the cork-tree, Lat. quercus suber:—its bark, cork, Lat. cortex, Pind., Aesch.

div1.head: Φελλώ
div1.sense: Cork-land, Luc.

div1.head: φενάκη
div1.sense: false hair, a wig, Luc.

div1.head: φενακίζω
div1.sense: to play the φέναξ, cheat, lie, Ar., Dem.
trans. to cheat, trick, τινά Ar., Dem.:—Pass. to be cheated, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: φενακισμός
div1.sense: cheatery, quackery, imposition, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: φέναξ
div1.sense: a cheat, quack, impostor, Ar.

div1.head: φένω†
div1.etym: forms such as πέφαται and πεφήσεαι from √φα
div1.sense: to slay, Hom., Soph.

div1.head: φερανθής
div1.sense: flower-bringing, Anth.

div1.head: φέρασπις
div1.sense: shield-bearing, Hhymn., Aesch.

div1.head: φέρβω
div1.etym: only in pres. and imperf., with plup. ἐπεφόρβειν.
div1.sense: to feed, nourish, Pind., Eur.; c. gen. to feed oxen on a thing, Hhymn.
= σῴζω, to preserve, Hes.
Pass. to be fed, feed upon a thing, Lat. pasci, vesci, παρέξω δαῖθʼ ὑφʼ ὧν ἐφερβόμην I shall make food for those by whom I feed myself, Soph.
to eat, feed on, c. acc., Lat. depasci, Eur.
to enjoy, have, νόον Pind.

div1.head: φερεαυγής
div1.sense: bringing light, Anth.

div1.head: φερέγγυος
div1.sense: giving surety:—generally, to be depended upon, trusty, sure, Aesch.:—c. inf. capable, sufficient, οὐ φ. εἰμι παρασχεῖν Hdt.; λιμὴν φ. διασῶσαι τὰς νέας Hdt.:—c. gen. rei, warrant for a thing, able to answer for, Soph.; so, φερεγγυώτατος πρὸς τὰ δεινά Thuc.

div1.head: φερέκακος
div1.sense: inured to toil or hardship, Polyb.

div1.head: φερέκαρπος
div1.sense: yielding fruit, Anth.

div1.head: φερένικος
div1.sense: carrying off victory, Pind.

div1.head: φερέοικος
div1.sense: carrying oneʼs house with one, of the Scythians, Hdt.:—as Subst. the house-carrier, i. e. snail, Hes.

div1.head: φερέπονος
div1.sense: bringing toil and trouble, Pind.

div1.head: φερέσβιος
div1.sense: life-giving, γαῖα Hhymn., Hes.

div1.head: φερεσσακής
div1.sense: shield-bearing, Hes.

div1.head: φερεστάφυλος
div1.sense: yielding bunches of grapes, Anth.

div1.head: φερετρεύομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be carried on a litter, Plut.

div1.head: φέρετρον
div1.sense: a bier, litter, Polyb.:—contr. φέρτρον Il.

div1.head: φέρμα
div1.sense: that which is borne, the fruit of the womb (cf. bairn from bear), Aesch.

div1.head: φερνή
div1.sense: that which is brought by the wife (cf. ἕδνον) , a dowry, portion, Lat. dos, Hdt., Eur.; also in pl. of a dower, as consisting of divers presents, Eur.; but, φερναὶ πολέμου, of a wife won in battle, Eur.:—in pl., also, bridal gifts, Eur.

div1.head: Φερρεφάττιον
div1.sense: a temple of Persephone, Dem.

div1.head: φέρτατος
div1.sense: bravest, best, Hom.:—of things, κακῶν φέρτατον the best, i. e. least bad, of two evils, Il.
in form φέριστος, Il.; mostly in voc. φέριστε, Il., Aesch., Soph.
comp., φέρτερος, η, ον, braver, better, Hom.:— πολὺ φέρτερόν ἐστιν ʼtis much better, Hom.;— τέττιγος φέρτερον ᾄδεις, as adv., Theocr.
div1.etym: The posit. occurs in προφερής· perh. the Root is φέρεσθαι, so that the orig. sense would be quick in action, vigorous.

div1.head: φερτός
div1.etym: verb. adj. of φέρω, endurable, Eur.

div1.head: φέρω
div1.etym: from Root !ἐνεκ or !ἐνεγκ come ἤνεγκον and ἤνεικα
div1.sense: Radic. sense, to bear, Lat. fero:
to bear or carry a load, Hom., Attic; of a woman with child, Aesch., Soph.
to bear, bear along, implying motion, πόδες φέρον Il.; horses are said ἅρμα φέρειν Il.; of a wind, Hom.; ὁ βορέας εἰς τὴν Ἑλλάδα φέρει is fair for Greece, Xen.

to bear, endure, suffer, Od., etc.; of wine, τὰ τρία φέρων bearing three parts of water, instead of ἴσον ἴσωι, Ar.:—often with Advs., βαρέως, δεινῶς, χαλεπῶς φέρειν τι, like Lat. aegre, graviter ferre, to bear impatiently, take ill or amiss, opp. to κούφως, ῥαιδίως φέρειν, Lat. leviter ferre, to bear patiently, take easily, Hdt., Attic:—such phrases are constructed mostly c. acc. rei; sometimes, c. dat. only, βαρέως φέρειν τοῖς παροῦσι Xen.
to bring, fetch, Hom., Attic:—Mid. to bring with one, or for oneʼs own use, Od., etc.
to bring, offer, present, δῶρα Od.; χάριν τινὶ φ. to grant any one a favour, do him a kindness, Hom., Attic
to bring, produce, work, cause, Hom.; φ. κακόν, πῆμα, ἄλγεα to work one woe, Hom.:— to produce, bring forward, cite, Dem.
to bring one word, to tell, announce, Aesch., etc.:—so in Mid., λόγους φ. Eur.; but also, ἔπος φέρεσθαι to have word brought one, receive, Eur.
to pay something due or owing, φόρον φέρειν to pay as tax or tribute, Thuc.; μισθὸν φ. Xen. (but also to receive pay, Ar., Thuc.):—of property, to bring in, yield as rent, Isae.
ψῆφον φ. to give oneʼs vote, Lat. ferre suffragium, Aesch.; ψῆφος καθʼ ἡμῶν οἴσεται (as Pass.) Eur.:—hence φέρειν τινά, to appoint to an office, Dem.
to bear, bring forth, produce, of the earth or of trees, Od., Hdt., etc.:—absol. to bear, bear fruit, be fruitful, Hdt.
to carry off or away, Il.: of stormy winds, Od.; of a river, Hdt.:—Mid. to carry off with one, Od., Xen., etc.
to carry off as booty or plunder, Il., etc.:—often in the phrase φέρειν καὶ ἄγειν, v. ἄγω I. 3:— φέρειν alone, to rob, plunder, θεῶν ἱερά Eur.; ἀλλήλους Thuc.:—Mid. in same sense, Hom.

to carry off, gain, win, achieve, Il., Soph., etc.; μισθὸν φέρειν (v. supr. IV. 5):—so in Mid. to win for oneself, Il., Attic:—metaph., τὰ πρῶτα, τὰ δεύτερα φέρεσθαι to win and hold the first, the second rank, Hdt.; πλέον or πλεῖον φέρεσθαι to gain the advantage over any one, τινος Hdt., etc.;—the Mid. being used of that which one gets for oneʼs own use, esp. to take home, Hdt.
absol., of roads, to lead to a place, ἡ ὁδὸς φέρει εἰς . . , like Lat. via fert or ducit ad . . , Hdt., Thuc., etc.
of a tract of country, to stretch, extend to or towards, like Lat. vergere or spectare ad . . , φέρειν ἐπί or ἐς θάλασσαν Hdt., etc.
metaph. to lead to, be conducive to, ἐς αἰσχύνην φέρει Hdt.; ἐς βλάβην φέρον Soph.

to aim at a thing, hint or point at, refer to it, εἰς or πρός τι Hdt., Plat.; so, τοῦ δήμου φέρει γνώμη, ὡς . . , the peopleʼs opinion inclines to this, that . . , Hdt.; τῶν ἡ γνώμη ἔφερε συμβάλλειν their opinion inclined to giving battle, Hdt.
impers. much like συμφέρει, it tends (to oneʼs interest), is conducive, φέρει σοι ταῦτα ποιεῖν; Hdt. d. intr., v. B. I. 2.

to carry in the mouth, i. e. to speak much of, Aeschin.: Pass., εὖ, πονηρῶς φέρεσθαι to be well or ill spoken of, Xen.: also absol. φέρεται, like Lat. fertur, [the report] is carried about, i. e. it is said, τοιόνδε φέρεται πρῆγμα γίγνεσθαι Hdt.
imperat. φέρε, like ἄγε, used as adv. come, now, well, φέρʼ εἰπὲ δή μοι Soph.; so, before 1 pers. sg. or pl. subj. used imperatively, φέρε ἀκούσω Hdt.; φ. δὴ ἴδωμεν, φ. δὴ σκεψώμεθα Plat.
before a question, φέρε τροπαῖα πῶς ἄρα στήσεις; well then, how wilt thou erect trophies? Eur.
part. neut. τὸ φέρον, as Subst. fortune, fate, τὸ φέρον ἐκ θεοῦ φέρειν χρή ye must bear what heaven bears to you, awards you, Soph.
Pass. is used in most of the above senses, esp.,
to be borne along by waves or winds, to be swept away, Od.; ἧκε φέρεσθαι he sent him flying, Il.; ἧκα πόδας καὶ χεῖρε φέρεσθαι I let go my hands and feet, let them swing free [in the leap], Od.

often in part. with another Verb of motion, φερόμενοι ἐσέπιπτον they fell on them with a rush, Hdt.; ὠιχόμην φερόμενος Plat.;—so, in part. act. used intr., φέρουσα ἐνέβαλε νηί she bore down upon the ship and struck it, Hdt.; φέρων hurriedly, in haste, Aeschin.
of voluntary motion, ἰθὺς φέρεται Il.; ὁμόσε τινὶ φέρεσθαι to come to blows with him, Xen., etc.

metaph., εὖ, κακῶς φέρεσθαι to turn out well or ill, succeed or fail, νόμοι οὐ καλῶς φέρονται Soph.; τὰ πράγματα κακῶς φέρεται Xen.; ἐᾶν ταῦτα φέρεσθαι to let these things take their course, Dem.:—of persons, εὖ φερόμενος ἐν στρατηγίαις being successful in his commands, Thuc.

div1.head: φεύγω
div1.etym: perfect passive participle πεφυγμένος has active meaning.
div1.sense: to flee, take flight, run away, Il.;—with Preps., φ. ἀπό or ἔκ τινος Hom., etc.; rarely c. gen. only, πεφυγμένος ἦεν ἀέθλων Od.:—c. acc. cogn., φεύγειν φυγήν Eur.; (so, φυγῆι φ. Plat.); φ. τὴν παρὰ θάλασσαν (sc. ὁδόν) to flee toward the sea, Hdt.

the pres. and imperf. properly express the endeavour to flee: hence the part. φεύγων is added to the compd. Verbs ἀποφεύγω, ἐκφεύγω, προφεύγω, to distinguish the attempt from the accomplishment, βέλτερον, ὡς φεύγων προφύγηι κακὸν ἠὲ ἁλώηι it is better that one should flee and escape than stay and be caught, Il.; φεύγων ἐκφ. Hdt., etc.
φ. εἰς . . to have recourse to .. , take refuge in . . , Eur.
c. inf. to be shy of doing, shrink from doing, Hdt., Plat.; and with the inf. omitted, to shrink back, Soph.

c. acc. to flee from, to shun, avoid, Hom., etc.; φ. φόνον to flee the consequences of the murder, Eur.:—the part. perf. pass. also retains the acc. in Hom., who joins it with εἶναι or γενέσθαι πεφευγέναι, e. g. μοῖραν δʼ οὔτινά φημι πεφυγμένον ἔμμεναι I say that no man can escape his doom, Il.; πεφυγμένον ἄμμε γενέσθαι Il.
of things, ἡνίοχον φύγον ἡνία the reins escaped from his hands, Il.
to flee oneʼs country for a crime, Hom.; οἱ φεύγοντες the exiles, Thuc.; φ. πατρίδα Od.
φ. ὑπό τινος to be banished by him, Hdt., Xen.:—absol. to go into exile, be an exile, Lat. exulare, Hdt.

as Attic law-term, to be accused or prosecuted: ὁ φεύγων the accused, defendant, Lat. reus, opp. to ὁ διώκων the accuser, prosecutor, Ar., Oratt.; c. acc., φ. γραφήν or δίκην to be put on oneʼs trial for something, Ar., Plat.; the crime being added in gen., φ. φόνου (sub. δίκην) to be charged with murder, Lys., etc.; φ. ἀσεβείας ὑπό τινος is accused of impiety by some one, Plat.

div1.head: φεύζω
div1.sense: to cry φεῦ, cry woe, only found once, τί τοῦτʼ ἔφευξας; Aesch.

div1.head: φευκτέος
div1.sense: one must flee, Eur.

div1.head: φευκτός
div1.sense: to be shunned or avoided, Arist.
that can be avoided, Soph.

div1.head: φευξείω
div1.sense: to wish to escape, Eur.

div1.head: φεῦ
div1.sense: exclamation of grief or anger, ah! alas! woe! like Lat. vah, vae,, Trag.; φεῦ τάλας Soph. etc.: c. ge., φεῦ τοῦ ὄρνιθος alas for the omen! aesch.
of astonishment or admiration, ah! oh! Eur. etc.; c. gen. φεῦ τοῦ ἀνδρός oh what a man! Xen.: c. acc., φεῦ τὸ καὶ λαβεῖν πρόσφεγμα τοιοῦδʼ ἀνδρός oh but to get the speech of such a man! Soph.

div1.head: φεψαλόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be burnt to ashes, Aesch.

div1.head: φέψαλος
div1.sense: a spark, piece of the embers, Ar.; ἀσπὶς ἐν τῷ φεψάλῳ κρεμήσεται, i. e. will be hung in the chimney, of things laid by and unused, Ar.

div1.head: φήγινος
div1.sense: oaken, Il.

div1.head: φηγός
div1.sense: a kind of oak, bearing an esculent acorn, quercus esculus, (not the Lat. fagus, our beech, though the names are identical), sacred to Ζεύς, Il., Soph.
the acorn of the same tree, Ar.

div1.head: φήληξ
div1.sense: a wild fig (prob. from φῆλος, deceitful, because it seems ripe when it is not really so), Ar.

div1.head: φηλητεύω
div1.sense: to cheat, deceive, Hhymn.

div1.head: φηλητής
div1.sense: a knave, thief, Hes., etc.

div1.head: φηλόω
div1.sense: to cheat, deceive, Aesch.: Pass., φηλούμενοι Eur.

div1.head: φήμη
div1.sense: Doric φάμα, Lat. fama: (φημί) :— a voice from heaven, a prophetic voice, Od.; so, when Ulysses prays to Zeus, φήμην τίς μοι φάσθω, he is answered by thunder, Od.; hence an oracle, divination, omen, Hdt., Soph., etc.
saying or report spread among men, rumour, Hes., Aeschin.; ὑποδεεστέρα τῆς φήμης inferior to the report of them, i. e. exaggerated, Thuc.
the talk or report of a manʼs character, Hes., etc.:—esp. good report, fame, Hdt., Pind.; also, φ. πονηραί Aesch., etc.
φᾶμαι songs of praise, Pind.
any voice or words, a speech, saying, Aesch.:—esp. a common saying, a tradition, legend, Eur., Plat.
a message, Trag.

div1.head: φημίζω
div1.sense: to utter a voice, φήμην φημίζειν Aesch.
to spread a report, Hes.: to prophesy, Aesch.:—Mid. to express in words, Hes.
in Mid. also to promise, τί τινι Eur.

div1.head: φημί
div1.etym: the imperf. act. should be ἔφην, like the aor2, but ἔφασκον was generally used instead.
div1.sense: Radical sense: to declare, make known; and so, to say, affirm, assert, either absol., or foll. by inf. or by acc.; the inf. is often omitted, σὲ κακὸν καὶ ἀνάλκιδα φήσει (sc. εἶναι) Il.; but also, Κορινθίους τί φῶμεν; what shall we say of them? Xen.:—then, since what one says commonly expresses a belief or opinion, to think, deem, suppose, Il.; φαίης κε ζάκοτόν τέ τινʼ ἔμμεναι ἄφρονά τε you would say, would think, he was . . , Il.; μὴ φαθὶ λεύσσειν think not that you see, Theocr.
Special Phrases:
φασί, they say, it is said, Hom., Attic; but in Prose also φησί, like French on dit, Dem.; (so Lat. inquit, ait).
φημί is sometimes joined with a synon. Verb. e.g. ἔφη λέγων, ἔφησε λέγων Hdt.; λέγει οὐδὲν φαμένη Hdt.
in repeating dialogues, the Verb commonly goes before its subject, ἔφην ἐγώ, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης said I, said Socrates; but the order is sometimes inverted, ἐγὼ ἔφην, ὁ Σωκράτης ἔφη I said, Socrates said.

in a more definite sense, like κατάφημι, to say yes, affirm, Hom., Attic; καὶ τοὺς φάναι and they said yes, Hdt.; καί φημι κἀπόφημι Soph.; whereas οὔ φημι means to say no, deny, refuse, ἡ Πυθίη οὐκ ἔφη χρήσειν said she would not answer, Hdt.; ἐὰν μὴ φῆι if he say no, Ar.; φάθι ἢ μή say yes or no, Plat.

div1.head: φῆμις
div1.sense: speech, talk, Hom.; δήμου φ. the voice or judgment of the people, Od.;— but δήμοιο φῆμις (Od. 15. 468) seems to be the place where the people talk, the place of assembly (ἀγορά) .
fame, reputation, Od.

div1.head: φήνη
div1.sense: prob. = ἁλιαίετος, the sea-eagle, Od., Ar.

div1.head: φηρομανής
div1.sense: game-mad, madly fond of wild animals, epith. of Bacchus, Anth.

div1.head: φήρ
div1.sense: Lat. fera, Pind.: pl. φῆρες, of the Centaurs, Il.

div1.head: φθάνω
div1.etym: φθανω always in Attic; φθᾱνω twice in Il.
div1.sense: to come or do first or before others:
c. acc. pers. to be beforehand with, overtake, outstrip, anticipate, Il., Hdt., Attic; so, ἔφθησαν τὸν χειμῶνα Hdt.:—Pass. to be overtaken, Anth.
absol. to come first, Eur., etc.; τοῦ φθάσαντος ἁρπαγή the prey of the first comer, Aesch.:—with Preps. to come or arrive first, ἐς τὸν Ἑλλήσποντον Thuc., etc.

the action in which one outstrips another is expressed by the part. agreeing with the subject, [Ἄτη φθάνει βλάπτουσα is beforehand in doing mischief, Il.; φθῆ μιν Τηλέμαχος βαλών Telemachus was beforehand with him in striking, Od.:—in translation, the part. often becomes the chief Verb and φθάνειν is rendered by an adv., quicker, sooner, first, before, beforehand, ἔφθησαν ἀπικόμενοι arrived first, Hdt.; so with part. pass. εἴ κε φθήηι τυπείς should he be wounded first, Il.; φθάνω εὐεργετῶν I am the first to shew a kindness, Xen.:— these clauses, being compar. in sense, are sometimes foll. by a gen., φθὰν ἱππήων κοσμηθέντες they were marshalled before the horsemen, Il.; or by πρὶν . . , πρὶν ἢ . . , ἔφθη ὀρεξάμενος, πρὶν οὐτάσαι Il.; ἔφθησαν ἀναβάντες πρὶν ἢ . . Hdt.

part. φθάς or φθάσας, Epic φθάμενος, used like an adv., ὅς μʼ ἔβαλε φθάμενος, for ὅς μʼ ἔφθη βαλών, Il.; οὐκ ἄλλος φθὰς ἐμεῦ κατήγορος ἔσται no other shall be an accuser before me, Hdt.; ἀνέωιξάς με φθάσας you opened the door before me, Ar.

rarely with the inf., like Lat. occuro, μόλις φθάνει θρόνοισιν ἐμπεσοῦσα μὴ χαμαὶ πεσεῖν hardly escapes falling on the ground by falling first on the seat, Eur.; φθάνει ἐλθεῖν he is first to come, Ar.

φθάνω with οὐ and part., followed by καί, like Lat. simul ac, denotes two actions following close on each other, οὐ φθάνειν χρὴ συσκιάζοντας γένυν, καὶ ὁρμᾶν you must no sooner get your beard, than you march, Ar.; οὐκ ἔφθη μοι συμβᾶσα ἡ ἀτυχία καὶ εὐθὺς ἐπεχείρησαν no sooner had misfortune befallen me, when they attempted, Dem.

οὐκ ἂν φθάνοις, οὐκ ἂν φθάνοιτε, with part. pres., denote impatience, οὐκ ἂν φθάνοιτε ἀπαλλασσόμενοι you could not be too quick in departing, i. e. make haste and be off, Hdt.; οὐκ ἂν φθάνοιτε τοῦτο πράττοντε Ar.; οὐκ ἂν φθάνοις λέγων Plat.:—so, the part. φθάσας is used with imperat., λέγε φθάσας speak quickly, τρέχε φθάσας, etc.
in answers, οὐκ ἂν φθάνοιμι I could not be too quick, i. e. I will begin directly, Plat.

div1.head: φθαρτικός
div1.sense: destructive of, τινος Arist.

div1.head: φθαρτός
div1.sense: perishable, Arist.

div1.head: φθέγγομαι
div1.sense: to utter a sound or voice, esp. to speak loud and clear, speak, Hom., etc.
of animals, as a horse, to neigh, whinny, Hdt.; of an eagle, to scream, Xen.; of a fawn, to cry, Theocr.
of inanimate things, of a door, to creak, Ar.; of thunder, to sound, Xen.; of musical instruments, Il.
= ὀνομάζω, to name, call by name, Plat.
c. acc. pers. to celebrate one aloud, extol, Pind.

div1.head: φθέγμα
div1.sense: the sound of the voice, a voice, Pind., Aesch., etc.: of a person, ὦ φθέγμʼ ἀναιδές, for ὦ φθεγξάμενε ἀναιδῆ, Soph.
language, speech, Soph.
a saying, word, Soph.
of other sounds, as of birds, cries, Soph., Eur.; of a bull, roaring, Eur.; φθ. θυείας the grinding of the mortar, Ar.; of the nightingaleʼs song, Ar.

div1.head: φθειρίασις
div1.sense: the morbus pedicularis, Plut.

div1.head: φθειριάω
div1.sense: to have morbus pedicularis, Plut.

div1.head: φθειροτραγέω
div1.sense: to eat fir-cones, Hdt.

div1.head: φθείρ
div1.sense: a louse, Lat. pediculus, Hdt., Ar.
a worm in vegetables, Luc.

div1.head: φθείρω
div1.sense: to ruin, waste, spoil, destroy, Lat. perdere, Od., Hdt., etc.:—Pass. to go to ruin, perish, Trag., etc.

Pass., (.] φθείρεσθε (as a curse) may ye perish! ruin seize ye! Il.; φθείρου plague take thee! away with thee! Lat. abi in malam rem! Ar.; so, εἰ μὴ φθερεῖ if thou depart not . . , Eur.; c. gen., φθείρεσθε τῆσδε off from her! i. e. unhand her, let her go, Eur.; φθείρεσθαι πρός . . to run headlong to . . , Dem.
to have suffered loss from shipwreck, Eur.
of women, χερσοὺς φθαρῆναι to pine away in barrenness, Soph.

div1.head: φθερσιγενής
div1.sense: destroying the race, Aesch.

div1.head: Φθία
div1.sense: Phthia in Thessaly, the home of Achilles, Hom.

div1.head: Φθίηφι
div1.sense: at Phthia, Il.

div1.head: φθίνασμα
div1.sense: as if from φθινάζω, a declining, sinking, Aesch.

div1.head: φθινάς
div1.sense: intr. waning, Eur.
act. causing to decline, wasting, Soph.

div1.head: φθινόκαρπος
div1.sense: having lost fruitfulness, Pind.

div1.head: φθινοπωρίς
div1.sense: autumnal, Pind.

div1.head: φθινόπωρον
div1.sense: late autumn, the fall of the year, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: φθινύθω
div1.etym: poetic for φθίνω, only in present and imperfect
div1.sense: trans. to waste, consume, Od.; φθ. κῆρ cause it to pine away, Od.
intr. to waste or pine away, decay, of men, Hom.

div1.head: φθίνυλλα
div1.sense: nickname for a thin or delicate woman, starveling, Ar.

div1.head: φθισήνωρ
div1.sense: destroying or killing men, Il., Hes.

div1.head: φθισίμβροτος
div1.sense: for φθισίβροτος, destroying men, Il., Od.

div1.head: φθίσις
div1.sense: a perishing, decay, Pind.:—of the moon, a waning, Arist.

div1.head: φθιτός
div1.etym: Trag. word, only used in pl. φθιτοί always without the Art.
div1.sense: the dead, Aesch., Eur.
liable to perish, Arist.

div1.head: φθίω
div1.etym: there is no diff. of sense in Act. and Pass.
div1.sense: to decay, wane, dwindle, of Time, πρίν κεν νὺξ φθῖτο (aor2 pass. opt.) first would the night be come to an end, Od.; so, τῆς νῦν φθιμένης νυκτός Soph.; φθίνουσιν νύκτες τε καὶ ἤματα they wane or pass away, Od.; μηδέ σοι αἰὼν φθινέτω let not thy life be wasted, Od.:— so, in the monthly reckoning, μηνῶν φθινόντων in the moonʼs wane, i. e. towards the monthʼs end, Od.:— μὴν φθίνων the ending of the month, v. ἵστημι B. III. 3.
of the stars, to decline, set, Aesch.

of men, to waste away, pine, perish, Hom., Eur.;—of things, to fade away, disappear, Soph.:—so in Pass., αὐτὸς φθίεται Il.; ἤδη φθίσονται Hom.:—often in part. φθίμενος, slain, dead, Il.; φθίμενοι the dead, φθιμένοισι μετείην Od., Trag.
Causal, in fut. φθίσω ῑ, aor1 ἔφθῑσα, to make to decay or pine away, to consume, destroy, Hom.; once in Aesch. φθίσας ι.

div1.head: Φθιώτης
div1.sense: a man of Phthia, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Φθιῶτις
div1.sense: Φθιῶτις, γῆ the land of Phthia, Eur., etc.; so Φθιάς, άδος, Eur.

div1.head: φθόγγος
div1.sense: any clear, distinct sound, esp. the voice of men, Hom., Attic; also of animals, Soph., Eur.
generally, a sound, as distinguished from a voice (φωνή) , Plat.:—of musical sounds, Eur.

div1.head: φθόϊς
div1.sense: a kind of cake, Ar.

div1.head: φθονερός
div1.sense: envious, jealous, grudging, of persons, Theogn., Attic:—adv., φθονερῶς ἔχειν to be enviously disposed, Plat., Xen., etc.

div1.head: φθονέω
div1.sense: to bear ill-will or malice, bear a grudge, be envious or jealous, Il., Xen., etc.:—c. dat. pers., πτωχὸς πτωχῷ φθονέει Hes.; φθ. τινὶ εὖ πρήσσοντι to envy him for his good fortune, Hdt.; also c. dat. rei, to feel envy at a thing, Isocr.; ἐπί τινι Xen.:—c. dat. pers. et gen. rei, οὔ τοι ἡμιόνων φθονέω I bear thee no grudge for the mules, Od.; μή μοι φθονήσῃς τοῦ μαθήματος Plat.:—c. gen. rei only, to be grudging of a thing, ἀλλοτρίων φθονέειν Od.

to refuse to do a thing from envy or ill-will, to grudge doing, c. inf., Od., Eur., etc.; μὴ φθονήσῃς do not refuse, Lat. ne graveris, μὴ φθ. διδάξαι Plat.:—also c. acc. et inf., ἐφθόνησαν οἱ θεοὶ ἕνα ἄνδρα βασιλεῦσαι Hdt.;—also c. dat. et inf., τῇ δʼ οὐκ ἂν φθονέοιμι ἅψασθαι; Od.
Pass. to be envied or begrudged, Lat. invideor, Hdt., Eur., etc.

div1.head: φθόνησις
div1.sense: a jealous refusal, Soph.

div1.head: φθόνος
div1.sense: ill-will, envy, jealousy, Lat. invidia, Hdt., etc.; φθόνον ἔχειν to feel envy or jealousy, Aesch.; but, also, to incur envy or dislike, Pind.; so, φθόνον ἀλφάνειν Eur., etc.:—c. gen. objecti, envy for, jealousy of, τῶν Ἑλλήνων φθόνῳ Hdt., etc.; but c. gen. subjecti, envy or jealousy felt by another, Eur., etc.:— in pl. envyings, jealousies, heartburnings, Isocr.
jealousy was ascribed to the gods, τὸν φθόνον πρόσκυσον deprecate their jealousy, Soph.
refusal from ill-will or envy, οὐδεὶς φθόνος, c. inf., said when you grant a request willingly, Plat.; so, ἀποκτείνειν φθόνος ἐστί ʼtis invidious, I dare not tell, Eur.

div1.head: φθορά
div1.sense: destruction, ruin, perdition, Hdt., Trag., etc.; and of men, mortality, death, esp. by pestilence, Thuc.
the decay of matter, Plat.
the seduction, Lex ap. Aeschin.

div1.head: φθόρος
div1.sense: ἴτʼ ἐς φθόρον φθείρεσθε (v. φθείρω II. 1) a common form of cursing, Aesch.; οὐκ ἐς φθόρον; Aesch.
like ὄλεθρος, a pestilent fellow, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: φιάλη
div1.sense: a broad, flat vessel, a bowl, used to boil liquids in, Il.; used as a cinerary urn, Il.
after Hom. a broad, flat bowl for drinking or pouring libations, Lat. patera, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: φιάλλω
div1.sense: to undertake, set about a thing, Ar.

div1.head: φιαρός
div1.sense: shining, bright, Theocr.

div1.head: φιβάλεως
div1.sense: a kind of early fig, called from Φίβαλις, a district of Attica or Megaris:—pl., nom. φιβάλεῳ, acc. φιβάλεως Ar.

div1.head: φιλάβουλος
div1.sense: wilfully unadvised, Anth.

div1.head: φιλάγλαος
div1.sense: loving splendour, Pind., Anth.

div1.head: φιλάγραυλος
div1.sense: fond of the country, Anth.

div1.head: φιλαγρευτής
div1.sense: fond of the chase, a hunter, Babr.:—fem. φιλ-αγρέτις, ιδος, Anth.

div1.head: φιλάγρυπνος
div1.sense: fond of waking, wakeful, Anth.

div1.head: φιλάγων
div1.sense: loving the games, Anth.

div1.head: φιλαδελφία
div1.sense: brotherly love, NTest.

div1.head: φιλάδελφος
div1.sense: loving oneʼs brother or sister, brotherly, sisterly, Soph., Xen.

div1.head: φιλάεθλος
div1.sense: fond of the games, Anth.

div1.head: φιλαθήναιος
div1.sense: fond of the Athenians, Ar.

div1.head: φιλαιδήμων
div1.sense: loving modesty, Anth.

div1.head: φιλαίματος
div1.sense: bloodthirsty, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: φιλαίτερος
div1.etym: irreg. comp. and Sup. of φίλος

div1.head: φιλαίτιος
div1.sense: fond of accusing, censorious, Xen., Dem.:— τὸ φ. censoriousness, Plut.
liable to blame or attack, Dem.

div1.head: φιλακόλουθος
div1.sense: readily following, Ar.

div1.head: φιλάκρατος
div1.sense: fond of sheer wine, Anth.

div1.head: φιλαλέξανδρος
div1.sense: a friend of Alexander, Strab.

div1.head: φιλαλήθης
div1.sense: loving truth, Arist.

div1.head: φιλάμπελος
div1.sense: loving the vine, Ar.

div1.head: φιλαμπελόω
div1.sense: to love the vine, Tzetz.

div1.head: φιλαναγνώστης
div1.sense: fond of reading, Plut.

div1.head: φιλαναλωτής
div1.sense: fond of spending, prodigal of, c. gen. rei, Plat.

div1.head: φιλανδρία
div1.sense: love for the male sex, Eur.
love for a husband, Luc., Anth.

div1.head: φίλανδρος
div1.sense: loving men, Aesch.
loving oneʼs husband, NTest.

div1.head: φιλανθρακεύς
div1.sense: friend of colliers, Ar.

div1.head: φιλανθρώπευμα
div1.sense: a humane act, Plut.

div1.head: φιλανθρωπεύομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to act humanely, πρός τινα Dem.

div1.head: φιλανθρωπέω
div1.sense: to treat humanely, Polyb.

div1.head: φιλανθρωπία
div1.sense: humanity, benevolence, kindliness, Plat., Xen., etc.:—in pl. acts of kindness, kindnesses, courtesies, Dem.
of God, love to man, NTest.
of things, ἡ τοῦ ὀνόματος φιλ. its humanity, kindliness, mildness, Dem.; ἡ φ. τῆς τέχνης, speaking of agriculture, Xen.

div1.head: φιλάνθρωπος
div1.sense: loving mankind, humane, benevolent, kindly, Aesch., Xen., etc.:—of dogs and horses loving men, gentle, Xen.
of things, humane, humanising, Xen., etc.
adv., φιλανθρώπως τινὶ χρῆσθαι Dem.

div1.head: φιλάνωρ
div1.sense: fond of oneʼs husband, conjugal, Aesch.

div1.head: φιλάοιδος
div1.sense: fond of singing, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: φιλαπεχθημοσύνη
div1.sense: fondness for making enemies, quarrelsomeness, Isocr., Dem.

div1.head: φιλαπεχθήμων
div1.sense: fond of making enemies, quarrelsome, Isocr., Dem. adv., φιλαπεχθημόνως ἔχειν to be quarrelsome, Plat.

div1.head: φιλαπλοϊκός
div1.sense: fond of simplicity, Luc.

div1.head: φιλαπόδημος
div1.sense: fond of travelling, Xen.

div1.head: φιλαργυρία
div1.sense: love of money, covetousness, Isocr., etc.

div1.head: φιλάργυρος
div1.sense: fond of money, covetous, Soph., Xen., etc.; Sup. φιλαργυρώτατος, Xen.:— τὸ φιλάργυρον φιλαργυρία, Plat.

div1.head: φιλάρετος
div1.sense: fond of virtue, Arist.

div1.head: φιλαριστείδης
div1.sense: a friend of Aristides, Anth.

div1.head: φιλάρματος
div1.sense: fond of the chariot-race, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: φιλαρχία
div1.sense: love of rule, lust of power, Theophr., Plut.

div1.head: φίλαρχος
div1.sense: fond of power, ambitious, Plat.

div1.head: φιλαστράγαλος
div1.sense: fond of playing at ἀστράγαλοι, Anth.

div1.head: φίλαυλος
div1.sense: fond of the flute, Soph., Eur., etc.

div1.head: φίλαυτος
div1.sense: loving oneself, Arist.

div1.head: φιλέγγυος
div1.sense: readily giving security or bail, Strab.

div1.head: φιλέθειρος
div1.sense: attached to the hair, Anth.

div1.head: φιλειδήμων
div1.sense: fond of learning, Strab.

div1.head: φιλέλλην
div1.sense: fond of the Hellenes, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: φιλεπιτιμητής
div1.sense: a censorious person, Isocr.

div1.head: φιλεραστής
div1.sense: fond of a lover, or fond of having lovers, Plat., Arist.

div1.head: φιλεραστία
div1.sense: devotion to a lover, Plat.

div1.head: φιλεργία
div1.sense: love of labour, industry, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: φιλεργός
div1.sense: loving work, industrious, Dem.

div1.head: φιλέριθος
div1.sense: fond of wool-spinning, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: φίλερως
div1.sense: prone to love, full of love, Anth.

div1.head: φιλέσπερος
div1.sense: fond of evening, Anth.

div1.head: φιλεταιρία
div1.sense: attachment to oneʼs comrades, Xen.

div1.head: φιλέταιρος
div1.sense: fond of oneʼs comrades or partisans, true to them, Thuc., Xen., etc.:—adv. -ρως, Aeschin.

div1.head: φιλεύιος
div1.sense: loving the cry of εὐοῖ, of Bacchus, Anth.

div1.head: φιλέω
div1.sense: to love, regard with affection, Lat. diligere, Hom., etc.; φ. τινὰ φιλότητα to feel affection for him, Od.; to love and cherish as oneʼs wife, Hom.:—the Epic aor1 mid. in act. sense, Il.
to treat affectionately or kindly, to welcome a guest, Hom.:—Pass., παρʼ ἄμμι φιλήσεαι welcome shalt thou be in our house, Od.
to kiss, Aesch., etc.; c. dupl. acc., τὸ φίλαμα, τὸ τὸν Ἄδωνιν φίλασεν the kiss wherewith she kissed him, Mosch.:—Mid. to kiss one another, Hdt.
of things, to love, like, approve, Od., Soph.
c. inf. to love to do, be fond of doing, and so to be wont or used to do, Hdt., Trag.

of things, events, αὔρα φιλέει πνέειν Hdt.; φιλεῖ μέγαλα στρατόπεδα ἐκπλήγνυσθαι great armies are apt to be seized with panic, Thuc.; πάντα ἀνθρώποισι φιλέει γίγνεσθαι everything comes to man by experience, Hdt.; and without γίγνεσθαι, οἷα δὴ φιλεῖ as is wont, Plat.; also impers., ὡς δὴ φιλεῖ as it is usual, Lat. ut solet, Plut.

div1.head: φιληδέω
div1.sense: to find pleasure in, take delight in a thing, c. dat., Ar.

div1.head: φιληδής
div1.sense: fond of pleasure, Arist.

div1.head: φιληδία
div1.sense: delight, Ar.

div1.head: φιλήδονος
div1.sense: fond of pleasure, Luc., etc.
wont to bring delight, Anth.

div1.head: φιληκοέω
div1.sense: to be attentive, Polyb.

div1.head: φιληκοΐα
div1.sense: fondness for hearing or listening to, c. gen., Isocr.

div1.head: φιλήκοος
div1.sense: fond of hearing discussions, Plat.

div1.head: φιληλάκατος
div1.sense: fond of the spindle, Anth.

div1.head: φιληλιάς
div1.sense: fond of the sun, Telesilla.

div1.head: φιληλιαστής
div1.sense: one who delights in the trials of the court Heliaea, Ar.

div1.head: φίλημα
div1.sense: a kiss, Eur., Xen., etc.

div1.head: φιλημοσύνη
div1.sense: friendliness, affection, Theogn.

div1.head: φιλήνεμος
div1.sense: loving wind: of a flute, played by the breath, Anth.

div1.head: φιλήνιος
div1.sense: following the rein, tractable, Aesch.

div1.head: φιλήρετμος
div1.sense: loving the oar, Od.

div1.head: φίλησις
div1.sense: a feeling of affection, Arist.

div1.head: φιλητέος
div1.sense: one must love, Soph.

div1.head: φιλητικός
div1.sense: disposed to love, τινος Arist.: absol. loving, affectionate, Arist.

div1.head: φιλητός
div1.sense: to be loved, worthy of love, Arist.; τὸ φ. the object of love, Arist.

div1.head: φιλήτωρ
div1.sense: a lover, Aesch.

div1.head: φιλία
div1.sense: friendly love, affection, friendship, distinct from ἔρως, as Lat. amicitia from amor, Hdt., Eur., etc.; φ. ποιεῖσθαι πρός τινα Xen.; with gen., διὰ φιλίαν αὐτοῦ through friendship for him, Thuc.; ἡμετέρη φ. friendship with us, Theogn.; φιλία ἡ ἐμή Xen., etc.
fondness for a thing, Plat.

div1.head: φιλικός
div1.sense: of or for a friend, befitting a friend, friendly, Xen., etc.:— φιλικά proofs or marks of friendship, Xen. adv. -κῶς, in a friendly way, Plat., etc.; φ. ἔχειν to be kindly disposed, Xen.

div1.head: Φίλιννα
div1.sense: prop. n. used as a term of affection, Darling, Ar.

div1.head: φίλιος
div1.sense: act. of or from a friend, friendly, Hdt., Trag., etc.; φ. τριήρης a friendly ship, Thuc.; ἡ φιλία (sc. γῆ, χώρα) a friendly country, opp. to ἡ πολεμία, Xen.
Ζεὺς φίλιος Zeus as god of friendship, Plat.; ναὶ τὸν φίλιον (sub. Δία) Ar.; πρὸς φιλίου Plat.
pass., beloved, dear, Trag.
adv. -ίως, Thuc., etc.

div1.head: φιλιππίζω
div1.sense: to be on Philipʼs side or party, to Philippize, Dem., Aeschin.

div1.head: Φιλιππικός
div1.sense: of or against Philip, Dem.

div1.head: φίλιππος
div1.sense: fond of horses, horse-loving, Pind., Eur., etc.:—Sup. φιλιππότατος, Xen.

div1.head: φιλίτια
div1.sense: the common meals or public tables at Sparta, Arist.

div1.head: φιλίτιον
div1.sense: the common hall in which the public table was kept, Xen., Plut.:—others read φιδίτιον or φειδίτιον -ια, (as if from φείδομαι) a frugal table, cheap dinner.

div1.head: φιλόβακχος
div1.sense: loving Bacchus or wine, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοβασίλειος
div1.sense: loving monarchy, Plut.

div1.head: φιλοβασιλεύς
div1.sense: a friend to the king, Plut.

div1.head: φιλόγαιος
div1.sense: loving the earth, Anth.

div1.head: φιλόγαμος
div1.sense: longing for marriage, Eur.

div1.head: φιλογαστορίδης
div1.sense: one who loves his belly, a glutton, Anth.

div1.head: φιλογέλοιος
div1.sense: fond of the ludicrous, Arist.

div1.head: φιλόγελως
div1.sense: laughter-loving, Plat., Arist.

div1.head: φιλογεωργία
div1.sense: fondness for a country life, Xen.

div1.head: φιλογέωργος
div1.sense: fond of a country life, Xen.

div1.head: φιλογηθής
div1.sense: loving mirth, mirthful, Aesch.

div1.head: φιλογραμματέω
div1.sense: to love books, Plut.

div1.head: φιλογράμματος
div1.sense: loving books, Plut., etc.

div1.head: φιλογυμναστέω
div1.sense: to love gymnastic exercises, Plat.

div1.head: φιλογυμναστία
div1.sense: fondness for gymnastic exercises, Plat.

div1.head: φιλογυμναστικός
div1.sense: of or for a φιλογυμναστής, Plat.

div1.head: φιλογύνης
div1.sense: fond of women, pl. φιλογύναικες Plat.

div1.head: φιλόδενδρος
div1.sense: fond of trees or the wood, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοδέσποτος
div1.sense: loving oneʼs lord or master, ἀνδράποδα φ. slaves that hug their chains, Hdt.; δῆμος φ. Theogn.

div1.head: φιλόδημος
div1.sense: a friend of the δῆμος, the commonsʼ friend, Ar.:— φ. ἔργον a popular act, Ar.

div1.head: φιλοδίκαιος
div1.sense: loving the right, loving justice, Arist.

div1.head: φιλοδικέω
div1.sense: to be fond of litigation, Thuc.

div1.head: φιλόδικος
div1.sense: fond of lawsuits, litigious, Lys., Dem.

div1.head: φιλοδίτης
div1.sense: a friend of travellers, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοδοξέω
div1.sense: to love fame, seek honour, ἐπί τινι for or in a thing, Arist.

div1.head: φιλοδοξία
div1.sense: love of honour or glory, Polyb.

div1.head: φιλόδοξος
div1.sense: loving honour or glory, Plat.: τὸ φιλόδοξον, φιλοδοξία, Luc.

div1.head: φιλόδουπος
div1.sense: loving noise, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοδωρία
div1.sense: fondness for giving, bounteousness, Luc.

div1.head: φιλόδωρος
div1.sense: fond of giving, bountiful, Xen.
of things, munificent, Dem.

div1.head: φιλοεργός
div1.sense: fond of work, industrious, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοζέφυρος
div1.sense: loving the west wind, Anth.

div1.head: φιλόζωος
div1.sense: fond of oneʼs life, Arist.

div1.head: φιλόζῳος
div1.sense: fond of animals, Xen.

div1.head: φιλοθεάμων
div1.sense: fond of seeing, fond of shows, plays or spectacles, Plat.; c. gen., φ. τῆς ἀληθείας Plat.

div1.head: φιλόθεος
div1.sense: loving God, pious, Arist., etc.

div1.head: φιλοθηρία
div1.sense: love of hunting, love of the chase, Xen.

div1.head: φιλόθηρος
div1.sense: fond of hunting, Xen., etc.: Sup. φιλοθηρότατος, Xen.

div1.head: φιλοθουκυδίδης
div1.sense: fond of Thucydides, Anth.

div1.head: φιλόθυτος
div1.sense: ὄργια φιλόθυτα, rites offered by zealous worshippers, Aesch.

div1.head: φιλοθύτης
div1.sense: fond of sacrifices, Ar.

div1.head: φιλοιερεύς
div1.sense: a friend of priests, Io. Damasc.

div1.head: φιλοίκειος
div1.sense: loving oneʼs relations, Arist.

div1.head: φιλοικοδόμος
div1.sense: fond of building, Xen.

div1.head: φιλοικτίρμων
div1.sense: prone to pity, Eur., Plat.

div1.head: φίλοικτος
div1.sense: moving pity, ἀπʼ ὄμματος βέλει φιλοίκτῳ with piteous glance shot from her eyes, Aesch.

div1.head: φιλοινία
div1.sense: love of wine, Hdt.

div1.head: φίλοινος
div1.sense: fond of wine, Plat., etc.

div1.head: φιλόκαινος
div1.sense: loving novelty or innovation: τὸ φιλόκαινον love of novelty, Luc.

div1.head: φιλοκαλέω
div1.sense: to cultivate a taste for the beautiful, Thuc.
to be eager, c. inf., Plut.

div1.head: φιλόκαλος
div1.sense: loving the beautiful, Plat., Xen., etc.: — fond of effect and elegance, Xen.
fond of honour, seeking honour, Xen.

div1.head: φιλοκαμπής
div1.sense: easily bending, lithe, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοκαρποφόρος
div1.sense: bearing fruit abundantly, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοκέρδεια
div1.sense: love of gain, greed, Xen.

div1.head: φιλοκερδέω
div1.sense: to be greedy of gain, Xen.

div1.head: φιλοκερδής
div1.sense: greedy of gain, Theogn., etc.

div1.head: φιλοκέρτομος
div1.sense: fond of jeering, Od., Theocr.

div1.head: φιλοκηδεμών
div1.sense: fond of oneʼs relatives, Xen.

div1.head: φιλοκίνδυνος
div1.sense: fond of danger, adventurous, Xen., Dem.; πρὸς τὰ θηρία φιλοκινδυνότατος Xen.:—adv. -νως, eagerly, Xen.
in bad sense, fool-hardy, Dem.

div1.head: φιλοκισσοφόρος
div1.sense: fond of wearing ivy, Eur.

div1.head: φιλόκνισος
div1.sense: fond of pinching, prurient, Anth.

div1.head: φιλόκοινος
div1.sense: fond of society, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοκόλαξ
div1.sense: fond of flatterers, Arist.

div1.head: φιλοκοσμία
div1.sense: love of ornament or show, Plut.

div1.head: φιλόκοσμος
div1.sense: loving ornament, Plut.

div1.head: φιλόκρημνος
div1.sense: loving steep rocks, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοκρόταλος
div1.sense: loving rattles, Anth.

div1.head: φιλόκροτος
div1.sense: loving noise, Hhymn.

div1.head: φιλοκτέανος
div1.sense: loving possessions, greedy of gain, covetous, Sup. φιλοκτεανώτατος, Il.

div1.head: φιλόκυβος
div1.sense: fond of dice, Ar.

div1.head: φιλοκυδής
div1.sense: loving glory, Hhymn.

div1.head: φιλοκύνηγος
div1.sense: loving the chase, Plut.

div1.head: φιλοκύων
div1.sense: fond of dogs, Plat.

div1.head: φιλολάκων
div1.sense: fond of the Laconians, Plut.

div1.head: φιλολήϊος
div1.sense: loving booty, Hhymn.

div1.head: φιλολογέω
div1.sense: to love learning, to study, Plut.

div1.head: φιλολογία
div1.sense: love of learning, studiousness, Isocr.

div1.head: φιλόλογος
div1.sense: fond of speaking, Plat.
fond of learning, literary, Lat. studiosus, Arist.

div1.head: φιλολοίδορος
div1.sense: fond of reviling, abusive, Dem.

div1.head: φιλομάθεια
div1.sense: love of learning, Plat.

div1.head: φιλομαθέω
div1.sense: to be fond of learning, Plat.

div1.head: φιλομαθής
div1.sense: fond of learning, eager after knowledge, Plat.; Sup. φιλομαθέστατος, Xen.; τὸ φιλομαθές φιλομάθεια, Plat.
c. gen. rei, eager after a thing, Plat., Xen.

div1.head: φιλόμαντις
div1.sense: one who takes note of divinations or omens, Luc.

div1.head: φιλόμαστος
div1.sense: loving the breast, Aesch.

div1.head: φιλομαχέω
div1.sense: to be eager to fight, Plut.

div1.head: φιλόμαχος
div1.sense: loving the fight, warlike, Aesch.

div1.head: φιλόμβριος
div1.sense: rain-loving, Anth.

div1.head: φιλομήλα
div1.sense: the nightingale, because, acc. to the legend, Philomela was changed into this bird, Dem.

div1.head: φιλόμηρος
div1.sense: fond of Homer, Strab.

div1.head: φιλομήτωρ
div1.sense: loving oneʼs mother, Plut.

div1.head: φιλομμειδής
div1.sense: laughter-loving, epith. of Aphrodite, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: φιλόμολπος
div1.sense: loving dance and song, Pind.

div1.head: φιλομουσία
div1.sense: love of the Muses, Luc.

div1.head: φιλόμουσος
div1.sense: loving the Muses, generally, loving music and the arts, Ar., Plat., etc.

div1.head: φιλομυθέω
div1.sense: to be fond of fables, Strab.

div1.head: φιλομυθία
div1.sense: a love of fables, Strab.

div1.head: φιλόμυθος
div1.sense: fond of legends or fables, Arist.
fond of talking, Arist.

div1.head: φιλοναύτης
div1.sense: loving sailors, Anth.

div1.head: φιλονικέω
div1.sense: to be fond of strife, engage in eager rivalry, be contentious, φιλονεικῶν out of contentiousness or party spirit, Thuc., Plat.; φ. πρός τινα Lys.:—c. acc., φ. τὸ ἐμὲ εἶναι τὸν ἀποκρινόμενον to be eager that I should be the answerer, Plat.; τὰ χείρω φ. to be so obstinate as to choose the worst, Thuc.
in good sense, to struggle emulously, φ. περὶ τῶν καλλίστων Isocr.

div1.head: φιλονικία
div1.sense: love of strife, eager rivalry, contentiousness, party-spirit, Thuc., etc.
in good sense, emulation, Xen.; διὰ φιλονεικίαν eagerly, Xen.

div1.head: φιλόνικος
div1.sense: fond of strife, eager for strife, contentious, Pind., Plat.
in good sense, emulous, of spirited horses, Xen.: τὸ φιλόνεικον φιλονεικία, Xen.:—adv. -κως, in eager rivalry, Xen., Plat., etc.

div1.head: φιλονύμφιος
div1.sense: loving the bridegroom or bride, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοξενία
div1.sense: hospitality, Theogn.

div1.head: φιλόξενος
div1.sense: loving strangers, hospitable, Od., Aesch.; παθεῖν φιλόξενον ἔργον to meet with an act of hospitality, Pind.

div1.head: φιλοπαίγμων
div1.sense: fond of play, playful, sportive, Od., Ar.

div1.head: φιλόπαις
div1.sense: loving its young, χελιδών Anth.

div1.head: φιλοπαράβολος
div1.sense: fond of daring, venturous, Plut.

div1.head: φιλοπατρία
div1.sense: love of oneʼs country, patriotism, Ar.

div1.head: φιλόπατρις
div1.sense: loving oneʼs country, Polyb., Luc.

div1.head: φιλοπάτωρ
div1.sense: loving oneʼs father, Eur.

div1.head: φιλοπευστέω
div1.sense: to be fond of inquiry, Polyb.

div1.head: φιλόπλεκτος
div1.sense: usually braided, Anth.

div1.head: φίλοπλος
div1.sense: loving arms, Anth.

div1.head: φιλόπλοος
div1.sense: fond of sailing, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοπλουτία
div1.sense: love of riches, Plut.

div1.head: φιλόπλουτος
div1.sense: loving riches, φ. ἅμιλλα eager pursuit of wealth, the race for riches, Eur.

div1.head: φιλοποιέω
div1.sense: Mid. to make oneʼs friend, attach to oneself, τινα Polyb.

div1.head: φιλοποιητής
div1.sense: a friend of poets, Plat.

div0.div1: φιλοποίμνιος φῐλο-ποίμνιος, ον, ποίμνη loving the flock, Theocr. 5.106[LSJ supp.]

div1.head: φιλοποιός
div1.sense: making friends, Plut.

div1.head: φιλοπόλεμος
div1.sense: fond of war, warlike, Il., Plut.: adv. -μως, Isocr.

div1.head: φιλόπολις
div1.sense: loving the city, Aesch.
loving oneʼs city, patriotic, Ar., Thuc.; τὸ φιλόπολι patriotism, Thuc.

div1.head: φιλοπολίτης
div1.sense: loving oneʼs fellow-citizens, Plut.

div1.head: φιλοπονέω
div1.sense: to love labour, work hard, be laborious or industrious, Xen., Plat.

div1.head: φιλοπονηρία
div1.sense: a love of bad men and actions, Theophr.

div1.head: φιλοπόνηρος
div1.sense: a friend to bad men, Plut.

div1.head: φιλοπονία
div1.sense: love of labour, laboriousness, industry, Plat.; φ. τινός laborious practice of a thing, Dem.

div1.head: φιλόπονος
div1.sense: loving labour, laborious, industrious, diligent, Soph., Plat.:—Sup. -ώτατος, Isocr.:—adv., φιλοπόνως ἔχειν to be diligent, Xen.
of things, toilsome, laborious, πόλεμος Xen.

div1.head: φιλοποσία
div1.sense: love of drinking, Xen., Plat.

div1.head: φιλοπότης
div1.sense: a lover of drinking, fond of wine, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: φιλοπραγμοσύνη
div1.sense: a busy disposition, meddlesomeness, restless habits of life, Plat., Dem.

div1.head: φιλοπράγμων
div1.sense: fond of business: in bad sense, a meddlesome fellow, busybody, Isae.

div1.head: φιλοπροσηγορία
div1.sense: easiness of address, Isocr.

div1.head: φιλοπροσήγορος
div1.sense: easy of address, affable, Isocr.

div1.head: φιλοπρωτεύω
div1.sense: to strive to be first, NTest.

div1.head: φιλόπρωτος
div1.sense: fond of being first: τὸ φιλόπρωτον eagerness to be first, Plut.

div1.head: φιλόπυρος
div1.sense: loving wheat, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοπωριστής
div1.sense: loving autumn-fruits, Anth.

div1.head: φιλόργιος
div1.sense: fond of orgies, Anth.

div1.head: φιλόρθιος
div1.sense: loving what is straight or right, Anth.

div1.head: φιλορμίστειρα
div1.sense: she who loves the harbour, Anth.

div1.head: φιλορνιθία
div1.sense: fondness for birds, Ar.

div1.head: φίλορνις
div1.sense: fond of birds, Plut.
loved or haunted by birds, Aesch.

div1.head: φιλορρώθων
div1.sense: attached to the nose, Anth.

div1.head: φιλορρώξ
div1.sense: loving grapes, Anth.

div1.head: φιλόρτυξ
div1.sense: fond of quails, Plat.

div1.head: φιλόσιτος
div1.sense: fond of corn, occupied about it, Xen.
fond of food, fond of eating, Plat.

div1.head: φιλόσκηπτρος
div1.sense: sceptred, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοσκήπων
div1.sense: loving a staff, of Pan, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοσκόπελος
div1.sense: loving rocks, Anth.

div1.head: φιλοσκώμμων
div1.sense: fond of scoffing or jesting, Hdt.

div1.head: φιλοσοφέω
div1.sense: to love knowledge, pursue it, philosophise, Lat. philosophari, Hdt., Thuc., etc.; φιλοσοφοῦντά με δεῖ ζῆν, says Socrates, Plat.
to teach philosophy, Isocr.
c. acc. to discuss philosophically, to investigate, study, Lat. meditari, Isocr.; φιλοσοφίαν φιλοσοφεῖν to pursue philosophy, Xen.
generally, to study a thing, Isocr.

div1.head: φιλοσοφητέος
div1.sense: one must pursue wisdom, Plat., etc.

div1.head: φιλοσοφία
div1.sense: love of knowledge and wisdom, pursuit thereof, speculation, study, Plat., etc.
the systematic treatment of a subject, investigation, Isocr.
philosophy, the investigation of truth and nature, Plat., etc.

div1.head: φιλόσοφος
div1.sense: a lover of wisdom, first used by Pythagoras, who called himself φιλόσοφος a lover of wisdom, not σοφός, a sage, Cic.: then in a wide sense of scientific men, learned men, Plat., etc.
a philosopher, i. e. one who speculates on the nature of things and truth, Ar., etc.; defined as ὁ τῆς ἀληθείας φιλοθεάμων, Plat.
as adj. loving knowledge, philosophic, Plat.: of arguments, etc., scientific, philosophic, Plat.; τὸ φιλόσοφον φιλοσοφία, Plat.
adv., φιλοσόφως διακεῖσθαι Isocr.; φ. ἔχειν Plat.

div1.head: φιλοσπῆλυγξ
div1.sense: fond of grottoes, Anth.

div1.head: φιλόσπονδος
div1.sense: used in drink-offerings, Aesch.

div1.head: φίλος
div1.etym: ι short: but voc. φίλε with ῑ in Hom.
div1.sense: pass. loved, beloved, dear, Lat. amicus, carus, Hom., etc.; c. dat. dear to one, Hom.; voc. φίλε may be used with neut. nouns, φίλε τέκνον Od.; a gen. was sometimes added to the voc., φίλʼ ἀνδρῶν Theocr.; ὦ φίλα γυναικῶν Eur.:—often as Subst., φίλος, a friend, Hom.:—proverb., ἔστιν ὁ φ. ἄλλος αὐτός a friend is another self, Arist.; κοινὰ τὰ τῶν φίλων Plat.:—so in fem. φίλη, a dear one, friend, Lat. amica, Hom., Attic:— φίλον, ου, an object of love, Soph.; τὰ φίλτατα oneʼs nearest and dearest, such as wife and children, Trag.

of things, dear, pleasant, welcome, Hom.:—as predic., φίλον ἐστί or γίγνεταί μοι ʼtis dear to me, pleases me, Lat. cordi est, Hom., Hdt., etc.; εἰ τόδʼ αὐτῷ φίλον κεκλημένῳ if it please him to be so called, Aesch.

in Poets, φίλος is used of oneʼs own limbs, life, etc., φίλον δʼ ἐξαίνυτο θυμόν he took away dear life, Il.; φίλον ἦτορ, φίλα γούνατα, πατὴρ φίλος, φίλη ἄλοχος Hom.; φίλην ἄγεσθαι to take as his own wife, Il.
in act. sense, like φίλιος, loving, friendly, Hom.; c. gen., φίλαν ξένων ἄρουραν friendly to strangers, Pind.; φίλα φρονέειν τινί to feel kindly, Il.; φ. ποιεῖσθαί τινι to make friends with one, Hdt.
adv. φίλως, φίλως χʼ ὁρόῳτε ye would fain see it, Il.; φ. ἐμοί in a manner dear or pleasing to me, Aesch.; φ. δέχεσθαί τινα Xen.
φίλος has several forms of comparison:
comp. φιλίων [ῐ], on, Od.
comp. φίλτερος, Sup. φίλτατος, v. sub vocc.
comp. φιλαίτερος, Sup. φιλαίτατος, Xen., Theocr.
in Attic μᾶλλον φίλος Aesch., etc.; Sup. μάλιστα φ. Xen.

div1.head: φιλοστέφανος
div1.sense: loving crowns, garlanded, Hhymn.

div1.head: φιλόστονος
div1.sense: loving sighs, piteous: adv. -νως, Aesch.

div1.head: φιλοστοργία
div1.sense: tender love, affectionateness, Xen.

div1.head: φιλόστοργος
div1.sense: loving tenderly, affectionate, of the love of parents and children, brothers and sisters, Xen., Theocr., etc.; τὸ φιλόστοργον φιλοστοργία, Xen.:—adv. φιλοστόργως, Plut.

div1.head: φιλοστρατιώτης
div1.sense: the soldierʼs friend, Xen.

div1.head: φιλοσώματος
div1.sense: loving the body, Plat.

div1.head: φιλότεκνος
div1.sense: loving oneʼs children or offspring, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: φιλοτεχνέω
div1.sense: to love art, practise an art, Plat.

div1.head: φιλότεχνος
div1.sense: fond of art, artistic, Plat.: τὸ φιλότεχνον ingenuity, Plut.

div1.head: φιλοτήσιος
div1.sense: of friendship or love, promoting it, Od., Soph.
ἡ φιλοτησία or -ήσιος (with or without κύλιξ) , the cup sacred to friendship, the loving-cup, Theogn., Ar.; φιλοτησίας προπίνειν (where φιλοτησίας is prob. acc. pl.), to drink healths, Dem.

div1.head: φιλότης
div1.sense: friendship, love, affection, Hom., etc.; φ. τινός friendship with, affection for, Od.; διὰ τὴν λίαν φιλότητα βροτῶν by his over great love for men, Aesch.; ὦ φιλότης, ὦ φίλε, my friend, Plat.

div1.head: φιλοτιμέομαι
div1.sense: to love or seek after honour, to be ambitious, emulous, jealous, Ar., etc.; φ. ὅτι . . to be jealous because . . , Xen.:—the object of ambition is added with a prep., φιλ. ἐπί τινι to pride oneself upon it, Xen., etc.; ἔν τινι Plat.;— with neut. adj., ἀεί τι φιλοτιμούμενος pursuing some object of ambition, Xen.
c. inf. to strive eagerly and emulously to do a thing, endeavour earnestly, aspire, Xen.:—c. acc. et inf. to be anxious that . . , Xen.

div1.head: φιλοτίμημα
div1.sense: an act of ambition or magnificence, Plut.
rivalry, Luc.

div1.head: φιλοτιμία
div1.sense: the character of the φιλότιμος, love of distinction, ambition, Eur., Thuc., etc.;—in good sense, Xen.: c. gen. objecti, φ. τινός emulous desire for a thing, Plat., etc.; φ. πρός τινα ambitious rivalry with him, Isocr.
ambitious pertinacity, obstinacy, Hdt.
ambitious display, prodigality, Dem., Aeschin.
the object coveted, honour, distinction, credit, Dem.

div1.head: φιλότιμος
div1.sense: loving honour, covetous of honour, ambitious, emulous, Eur., Plat., etc.; in good sense, Xen., Isocr.:—with abstr. Nouns (in both senses), εὐχά Aesch.; ἦθος Eur.; σοφίαι Ar.; φ. ἐπί τινι eager to be honoured for a thing, covetous of distinction in . . , ἐπὶ σοφίᾳ, ἐπʼ ἀρετῇ Plat.
emulously prodigal, lavish, Dem.
in pass. sense, = πολυτίμητος, august, Aesch.
adv. -μως, ambitiously, emulously, φ. ἔχειν to vie emulously, Plat.; φ. ἔχειν πρός τι to strive, exert oneself eagerly after a thing, Xen.

div1.head: φιλοτοιοῦτος
div1.sense: fond of such and such things, Arist.

div1.head: φιλοτύραννος
div1.sense: friend of tyranny, Plut.

div1.head: φιλόφθογγος
div1.sense: loving noise, noisy, Anth.

div1.head: φιλόφιλος
div1.sense: loving oneʼs friends, Arist.

div1.head: φιλοφρονέομαι
div1.sense: to treat affectionately, to shew kindness to, τινα Hdt., Plat.; φ. τινα τῆι δικέλληι to entertain him with a blow of the mattock, Luc.

c. dat., φιλοφρονήσασθαί τινι to shew a favour to one, Xen.:—aor1 pass. φιλοφρονηθῆναι, in a reciprocal sense, to shew kindness one to another, to greet one another, Luc.; so φιλοφρονήσασθαι ἀλλήλους Luc.
absol. to be of a kindly, cheerful temper, Luc.

div1.head: φιλοφροσύνη
div1.sense: friendliness, kindliness, Il.; τινός towards one, Hdt.; πρός τινα Plat.: pl. friendly greetings, Pind.
cheerfulness, Xen.

div1.head: φιλόφρων
div1.sense: kindly minded, kindly, friendly, affable, Pind., Aesch., etc.: adv., φιλοφρόνως ἀσπάζεσθαι to greet kindly, Hdt.; φ. ἔχειν πρός τινα to be kindly minded towards one, Xen.

div1.head: φιλοχορευτής
div1.sense: friend of the choral dance, Ar.

div1.head: φιλόχορος
div1.sense: loving the choir or choral dance, Aesch.

div1.head: φιλοχρηματέω
div1.sense: to love money, Plat.

div1.head: φιλοχρηματία
div1.sense: love of money, Plat.

div1.head: φιλοχρηματιστής
div1.sense: fond of money-making, Plat.

div1.head: φιλοχρήματος
div1.sense: loving money, fond of money, Plat., etc.: τὸ φιλοχρήματον φιλοχρηματία, Plat.; Sup. -ώτατος, Diod. adv., φιλοχρημάτως ἔχειν φιλοχρηματεῖν, Isocr.

div1.head: φιλόχρηστος
div1.sense: loving goodness or honesty, Xen.

div1.head: φιλόχρυσος
div1.sense: fond of gold, Luc., Anth.

div1.head: φιλοχωρέω
div1.sense: to be fond of a place, to abide there always, haunt it, Hdt.

div1.head: φιλοχωρία
div1.sense: fondness for a place, love of oneʼs haunts, local attachment, Ar.

div1.head: φιλοψευδής
div1.sense: fond of lies or lying, Il., Plat.

div1.head: φιλόψογος
div1.sense: fond of blame, censorious, Eur., Plat.

div1.head: φιλοψυχέω
div1.sense: to love oneʼs life: to be cowardly or faint-hearted, Tyrtae., Eur.

div1.head: φιλοψυχητέος
div1.sense: one must love life, Plat.

div1.head: φιλοψυχία
div1.sense: love of life, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: φιλόψυχος
div1.sense: loving oneʼs life, cowardly, dastardly, faint-hearted, Eur.

div1.head: φίλτατος
div1.etym: irreg. Sup. of φίλος, Hom., Trag.

div1.head: φίλτερος
div1.etym: irreg. comp. of φίλος, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: Φιλτραῖος
div1.sense: charmer, name of a mouse, Batr.

div1.head: φίλτρον
div1.sense: a love-charm, (cf. Shakspeareʼs "medicines to make me love him"), ἐστὶν φίλτρα μοι θελκτήρια ἔρωτος Eur.; of the robe of Nessus by which Deianira hoped to win back the love of Hercules, Soph.

generally, a charm, spell, as a means of winning or influencing others, hence the bit is called φ. ἵππειον, Pind.; Apolloʼs oracles are φίλτρα τόλμης spells to produce boldness, Aesch.; children are a φίλτρον of love to their parents, Eur., etc.
in pl. love, affection, Eur.

div1.head: φιλύδρηλος
div1.sense: loving moisture, Anth.

div1.head: φιλύρα
div1.sense: the lime or linden tree, Lat. tilia, Hdt.

div1.head: φιλύρινος
div1.sense: of the lime or linden tree, light as linden wood, Ar.

div1.head: φιλωρείτης
div1.sense: a lover of mountains, Anth.

div1.head: φιμός
div1.sense: a muzzle, Lat. capistrum, Luc.
the nose-band of a horseʼs bridle, fitted with pipes through which the horsesʼ breath made a whistling sound, Aesch.
a kind of cup, used as a dice-box, Lat. fritillus, Aeschin.

div1.head: φιμόω
div1.sense: to muzzle, shut up as with a muzzle, φ. τῷ ξύλῳ τὸν αὐχένα to make fast his neck in the pillory, Ar.: metaph. to muzzle, put to silence, NTest.: Pass., aor1 imperat. φιμώθητι be thou silenced, NTest.

div1.head: -φι
div1.sense: -φι, -φιν, an old term. of dat. for -ῃ, ας, ᾖφι βίῃφι πεποιθώς; for -ῳ, as θεόφιν ἀτάλαντος; also pl., as, ; ναῦφι for ναυσί.
of gen., for -ης, as, ἐξ εὐνῆφι; for -ου, as, ἐκ θεόφιν, for -ος, κράτεσφι for κρᾱτός, of the head.

div1.head: φ
div1.sense: φ, φῖ, τό, indecl., twenty-first letter of the Gr.
changes of φ:

in Aeolic, Doric and Ionic the aspirate was often dropped, and φ became π, as in ἀσπάραγος σπόγγος σπυράς for ἀσφάραγος σφόγγος σφυράς, whereas the Attic sometimes used φ for π, as φανός φάτρα for πανός πάτρα.
in Aeolic, Doric, and Ionic φ is sometimes put for θ, as φήρ φλάω for θήρ θλάω.
older Poets sometimes treated φ as a double consonant, so that a short vowel before it becomes long by position, as in ὄφις, Ζεφύριος quasi ὄπφις, Ζεπφύριος.

div1.head: φιτρός
div1.sense: a block of wood, log, Hom.

div1.head: φίτυμα
div1.sense: a shoot, scion, of a son, Aesch.

div1.head: φιτυποίμην
div1.sense: a tender of plants, gardener, Aesch.

div1.head: φιτύω
div1.etym: poet. for φυτεύω, when the 1st syll. is to be long
div1.sense: to sow, plant, beget, call into being, Trag.:—Mid. of the woman, to produce, bear, Hes.; Epic 2nd sg. fut. φιτύσεαι Mosch.

div1.head: φλάζω
div1.sense: to be rent with a noise, Aesch.

div1.head: φλαττόθρατ
div1.sense: Comic words in Ar., meant to ridicule a bombastic style— "sound without sense."

div1.head: φλαῦρος
div1.sense: petty, paltry, trivial, Solon., Pind., Hdt.
paltry, sorry, indifferent, bad, Aesch., Soph.; φλαῦρον ἐργάζεσθαί τινα to do one a mischief, Ar.; φλαῦρον εἰπεῖν τινα to speak disparagingly of him, Ar.
useless, Soph.
of persons, οὐ φλαυροτάτους τιμωρούς not the meanest or weakest avengers, Hdt.; τῆς στρατιῆς τὸ φλαυρότατον the least serviceable part, Hdt.
shabby, plain, of personal appearance, Hdt.
bad, opp. to χρηστός, Eur.

adv., φλαύρως ἔχειν to be ill, Hdt.; φλ. ἔχειν τινός to be ill off for a thing, Thuc.; but, φλαύρως ἔχειν τὴν τέχνην to know an art badly, Hdt.; φλ. ἀκούειν, like Lat. male audire, to be ill spoken of, Hdt.

div1.head: φλαυρουργός
div1.sense: working badly, ἀνὴρ φλ. a sorry workman, Soph.

div1.head: φλάω
div1.sense: to crush, pound, Pind.
to bruise with the teeth, eat up, eat greedily, Pind.

div1.head: φλεγέθω
div1.sense: trans. to burn, scorch, burn up, Il.:—Pass., ὄφρα πυρὶ φλεγεθοίατο νεκροί Il.
intr. to blaze, flare up, of fire, Il.; of the sun, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: φλεγμαίνω
div1.sense: to be heated, inflamed, to fester, φλεγμαίνουσα πόλις, opp. to ὑγιής, Plat.

div1.head: φλέγμα
div1.sense: flame, fire, heat, Il.
inflammation, heat: also phlegm, a morbid humour, Lat. pituita, Hdt.:—in Poets, like χολή, gall, bile, Anth.

div1.head: φλεγματώδης
div1.sense: inflammatory, Plat.

div1.head: Φλέγρα
div1.sense: Phlegra, an ancient name for Pallene in Thrace, Hdt.; Φλέγρας πεδίον, in which the giants are said to have been conquered by the gods, Pind., Ar.; Φλεγραία πλάξ Aesch.; also Φλέγραι, Pind.

div1.head: φλεγύας
div1.sense: fiery red, red-brown, of the eagle (μόρφνος) , Hes.

div1.head: φλεγυρός
div1.sense: burning: metaph. ardent, Ar.

div1.head: φλέγω
div1.sense: trans. to burn, burn up, Il., Aesch.:—Pass. to take fire, blaze up, Il.
metaph. to kindle, inflame with passion, Soph., Eur.:—Pass., like Lat. uri, to burn with passion, be inflamed, Soph., Ar.
to light up, Ζεὺς βέλος φλέγων making it blaze or flash, Aesch.; metaph., ἄταν οὐρανίαν φλέγων letting the flame of mischief blaze up to heaven, Soph.:—Pass. to blaze up, be a-light, Aesch.
metaph. to make illustrious or famous, Lat. illustrare, Pind.:—Pass. to be or become so, Aesch.
intr. to burn, flame, blaze, Aesch., Soph.; of armour, to flash, Eur.
metaph. to break forth, of passion, Aesch.
to shine forth, become famous, Pind.

div1.head: φλέδων
div1.sense: a babbler; of a woman, Aesch.

div1.head: φλέξις
div1.sense: an unknown bird, Ar.

div1.head: φλέψ
div1.sense: a vein, Il., etc.; φλέβα σχάζειν to open a vein, Xen.
a vein of metal, Xen.

div1.head: φλέω
div1.sense: to teem with abundance, abound, Aesch.

div1.head: φλέως
div1.sense: a kind of flowering rush or reed, Ar.

div1.head: φληναφάω
div1.sense: to chatter, babble, Ar.

div1.head: φλήναφος
div1.sense: idle talk, nonsense, Luc.

div1.head: φλιά
div1.sense: in pl. φλιαί, σταθμοί, the doorposts, jambs, Od., Bion.; in sg., Theocr.

div1.head: Φλειάσιος
div1.sense: Phliasian, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Φλειοῦς
div1.sense: Phlius, in the North of Peloponnesus, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: φλόγεος
div1.sense: burning, flaming, Il., Eur.

div1.head: φλογερός
div1.sense: flaming, fiery-red, Eur.

div1.head: φλογίζω
div1.sense: to set on fire, burn, burn up, Soph.:—Pass. to be set on fire, to blaze, flame, ???: metaph., of the tongue, NTest. Hence

div1.head: φλογιστός
div1.sense: burnt up, Soph.

div1.head: φλογμός
div1.sense: flame, blaze, as of lightning, Eur.; fiery heat, Aesch.; feverish heat, Luc.

div1.head: φλογόω
div1.sense: Mid.-Pass. to blaze, Theophr.

div1.head: φλογωπός
div1.sense: fiery-looking, flaming, Aesch.; φλ. σήματα omens by fire (not lightning), Aesch.

div1.head: φλόγωσις
div1.sense: burning heat, inflammation, Thuc.

div1.head: φλόϊνος
div1.sense: of or from the water-plant φλέως (Ionic φλοῦς) , ἐσθῆτες φλόϊναι mat- garments, Hdt.

div1.head: φλοιός
div1.sense: the bark of trees, bast or bass, smooth bark, Il., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: φλοῖσβος
div1.sense: any confused noise, the noise of battle, the battle-din, Il.; the roar of the sea, Aesch.

div1.head: φλόξ
div1.sense: a flame of fire, Hom.; φλόγα δαίειν to kindle a flame, Il.; ἐγείρειν Xen.; σβέσαι to put it out, Thuc.; also of lightning, Aesch., Eur.; of the heat of the sun, Aesch.; the flame or flash of a bright helmet, Il.; —φλ. οἴνου the fiery strength of wine, Eur.

div1.head: φλόος
div1.sense: rarer form of φλοιός, Anth.
φλοῦς, Ionic for φλέως, Hdt.

div1.head: φλυαρέω
div1.sense: to talk nonsense, play the fool, Lat. nugari, Hdt., Ar.:— c. acc. cogn., φλυαρίαν φλυαρεῖν Plat.

div1.head: φλυαρία
div1.sense: silly talk, nonsense, foolery, Ar., Plat., etc.; often in pl. fooleries, Lat. nugae, Plat.

div1.head: φλύαρος
div1.sense: silly talk, foolery, nonsense, Ar.
a silly talker, tatler, babbler, Plat., NTest.

div1.head: φλυαρώδης
div1.sense: fooling, Plut. fl4uzw, v. φλύω.

div1.head: φλύκταινα
div1.sense: a blister caused by rowing, Ar.: of pustules caused by plague, Thuc.
a blister on bread, Luc.

div1.head: φλύω
div1.sense: to boil over, bubble up: metaph. to overflow with words, talk idly, babble, brag, Aesch.

div1.head: φοβερός
div1.sense: fearful, whether act. or pass.:

act. causing fear, dreadful, terrible, formidable, Hdt., Aesch., etc.; πλήθει φ. formidable only from numbers, Thuc.; c. inf., φ. ἰδεῖν, φ. προσιδέσθαι fearful to behold, Aesch., Eur.: τὸ ξύνηθες τοῖς πολίταις φοβερόν the terror habitual to the people, Thuc.

matter for fear, regarded with fear, οὐδὲ ὅρκος φ. Thuc.; φοβεροὶ ἦσαν μὴ ποιήσειαν they gave cause for fear lest . . , Xen.; τὸ φ. terror, danger, Xen.; φοβερόν ἐστι μὴ . . there is reason to dread that . . , Xen.
pass. feeling fear, afraid, timid, Soph., Thuc., etc.
caused by fear, panic, Thuc.; φ. φροντίδες anxious thoughts, Plat.
adv. -ρῶς, in both senses, Xen., etc.; comp., φοβερώτερον, Sup., -ώτατα, Xen.
