div1.head: φοβερότης
div1.sense: terribleness, Arist.

div1.head: φοβεσιστράτη
div1.sense: scarer of hosts, Ar.

div1.head: φοβέω
div1.sense: Act. to put to flight, Lat. fugo, Il.
to strike with fear, to terrify, frighten, alarm, Lat. terreo, Hdt., Attic; πόνος ὁ μὴ φοβῶν free from alarm, Soph.; φοβήσαντες κατεστήσαντο τὴν πολιτείαν they established it by terror, Plat.
Pass. and Mid. to be put to flight, to flee affrighted, flee, Hom.; φοβηθείς in flight, Il.; ὑπό τινος φοβέεσθαι to flee before him, Il.

to be seized with fear, be affrighted, fear, Hdt., Attic; φοβεῖσθαι εἴς or πρός τι to be alarmed at a thing, Soph.; ἀμφί τινι to fear about a thing, Hdt.; περί τινος Xen.; περί τινι Thuc., etc.:— φοβεῖσθαι μὴ . . to fear lest a thing will be, Lat. vereri ne . . , Eur., etc.; so, φ. ὅπως μὴ . . Thuc.; so, φοβ. ὅτι . . , ὡς . . to fear that . . , not like Lat. vereri ut . . , Thuc., etc.:— φοβ. c. inf. to fear to do, be afraid of doing, Aesch., Trag.
c. acc. pers. to stand in awe of, dread, fear, Soph., etc.: c. acc. rei, to fear or fear about a thing, Soph.

div1.head: φόβημα
div1.sense: a terror, τινος to one, Soph.

div1.head: φόβη
div1.sense: a lock or curl of hair, Aesch., Soph.
the mane of a horse, Eur.
metaph., like κόμη, the tresses of trees, foliage, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: φοβητέος
div1.sense: one must fear, Plat.
φοβητέος, η, ον, to be feared, Plat.

div1.head: φοβητικός
div1.sense: liable to fear, fearful, timid, Arist.

div1.head: φοβητός
div1.sense: to be feared, τινι Soph.

div1.head: φόβητρον
div1.sense: a scarecrow, terror, in pl. terrors, Plat., NTest.

div1.head: φόβος
div1.sense: flight, Lat. fuga, the only sense in Hom.; φόβονδε φύγαδε, μή τι φόβονδʼ ἀγόρευε counsel not to flight, Il., etc.:— Φόβος is personified as son of Ares, Il., Hes.

panic fear, such as causes flight, στρατῷ φ. ἐμβάλλειν Hdt.:—then generally, fear, terror, properly of the outward show of fear, and so distinguished from δέος (the sensation of fear), Aesch., etc.: the Object of fear is in gen., fear of another, Aesch., etc.; so φ. ἀπό τινος Xen.; ἔκ τινος Aesch.; πρός τινος Soph.;—but, φ. περί or ὑπέρ τινος fear for or concerning . . , Thuc.:—with Verbs, ποιεῖν or παρέχειν τινί Xen.; φόβον ἐμβάλλειν, ἐντιθέναι τινί to strike terror into one, Lat. metum incutere alicui, Xen., etc.;—of the person who feels fear, φόβον λαμβάνειν Eur.; φόβος ἔχει με Aesch.; φ. ἐμπίπτει μοι Xen.; διὰ φόβου ἔρχομαι Eur.:—also in pl., Aesch., etc.
an object of terror, a terror; φόβος ἀκοῦσαι a terror to hear, Hdt.:—pl., ἢν φόβους λέγῃ Soph.

div1.head: φοιβάζω
div1.sense: to prophesy, Anth.

div1.head: φοιβάς
div1.sense: a priestess of Phoebus: generally, a prophetess, Eur.

div1.head: φοιβαστικός
div1.sense: prophetic: c. gen., φ. χρησμῶν uttering oracles, Plut.

div1.head: φοιβάω
div1.sense: to cleanse, purify, Theocr.

div1.head: Φοίβειος
div1.sense: of Phoebus, sacred to him, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: Φοίβη
div1.sense: Lat. Phoebe, one of the daughters of Uranus and Gaia, Hes.; mother of Phoebus, Aesch.

div1.head: φοιβόληπτος
div1.sense: possessed by Phoebus, Plut.:— Ionic φοιβό-λαμπτος, Hdt.

div1.head: φοῖβος
div1.sense: bright, radiant, Aesch.
as prop. n., Φοῖβος, Phoebus, i. e. the bright or pure: Hom. commonly joins Φοῖβος Ἀπόλλων, but also has Φοῖβος alone.

div1.head: φοινήεις
div1.sense: blood-red, Il., Mosch.

div1.head: φοινικάνθεμος
div1.sense: with purple flowers, Pind.

div1.head: φοινίκεος
div1.sense: purple-red, purple or crimson, and (generally) red, Lat. puniceus, Hdt., Pind.:—Attic contr. φοινῑκοῦς, ᾶ, οῦν, Xen.

div1.head: φοινικήϊος
div1.sense: of the date-palm, ἐσθὴς φοινικηίη a garment of palm leaves, Hdt.; φ. οἶνος palm- wine, Hdt.
Phoenician, Hdt.; Φοινικήια γράμματα, of the ancient Ionic alphabet, Hdt.

div1.head: Φοινίκη
div1.sense: Phoenicia, Od., etc.; cf. Φοῖνιξ.
the country of Carthage, Eur.

div1.head: Φοινικικός
div1.sense: Phoenician, Hdt., etc.; sometimes to express great antiquity, Plat.:—later, Punic, to express treachery, Polyb.
φοινικικός, φοινίκεος· metaph., κακὰ φοινικικά "of deep dye, " Ar. φοινῑκιοῦς, οῦσσα, οῦν, φοινίκεος, Ar.

div1.head: φοινικίς
div1.sense: a red or purple cloth, Ar., Xen.
a red cloak, Ar.; φοινικίδʼ ὀξεῖαν πάνυ a red cloak as bright as bright can be, Ar.
a red curtain or carpet, Aeschin.
a red flag, Lys., Polyb.

div1.head: φοινικιστής
div1.sense: with the Persians, a wearer of purple, i. e. one of the highest rank, Lat. purpuratus, Xen.

div1.head: Φοινικιστί
div1.sense: in the Phoenician tongue, Polyb.

div1.head: φοινικόβαπτος
div1.sense: purple-dyed, ἐσθήματα Aesch.

div1.head: φοινικοβατέω
div1.sense: to climb palms, Luc.

div1.head: φοινικοδάκτυλος
div1.sense: crimson-fingered, Arist.

div1.head: φοινικόεις
div1.sense: dark-red, purple or crimson, Hom., Hes.
div1.etym: In hexam., φοινικόεσσαν, -όεντα, are pronounced as if contracted.

div1.head: φοινικόκροκος
div1.sense: of purple woof, Pind.

div1.head: φοινικόλοφος
div1.sense: purple or crimson-crested, Eur.

div1.head: φοινικοπάρηος
div1.sense: red-cheeked, epith. of ships, the bows of which were painted red, Od.

div1.head: φοινικόπεζα
div1.sense: ruddy-footed, epith. of Demeter: prob. from the colour of ripe corn, Virgilʼs rubicunda Ceres, Pind.

div1.head: φοινικόπτερος
div1.sense: red-feathered: name of a waterbird, perh. the flamingo, Ar.

div1.head: φοινικοσκελής
div1.sense: red-legged, Eur.

div1.head: φοινικοστερόπας
div1.sense: hurler of red lightnings, Ζεύς Pind.

div1.head: Φοινικόστολος
div1.sense: sent by Phoenicians, Φοιν. ἔγχεα, i. e. ἔγχεα τοῦ τῶν Φοινίκων στόλου, Pind.

div1.head: φοινικοφαής
div1.sense: ruddy-glancing, πούς Eur.

div1.head: Φοῖνιξ
div1.sense: a Phoenician, Hom.
fem., Φοίνισσα γυνή Od., Eur.; χθών, νῆσος Eur.

div1.head: φοῖνιξ
div1.sense: appellat. a purple-red, purple or crimson, because the discovery and earliest use of this colour was ascribed to the Phoenicians, Hom.

as adj., ὁ, (also φοίνισσα as fem. in Pind.), red, dark red, of a bay horse, Il.; of red cattle, Pind.; of fire, Pind., Eur.:— φοῖνιξ and its derivs. included all dark reds, from crimson to purple, while the brighter shades were denoted by πορφύρεος, ἁλουργής, κόκκινος.
the date-palm, palm, Od., Eur., etc.
the fabulous bird phoenix, which came from Arabia to Egypt every 500 years, Hdt.:—proverb., φοίνικος ἔτη βιοῦν Luc.

div1.head: φοίνιος
div1.sense: when the first syll. is to be long, of or like blood, blood-red, red, Od., Aesch., Soph.
bloody, blood-stained, murderous, Pind., Aesch., etc.

div1.head: φοινίσσω
div1.sense: to redden, make red, Orac. ap. Hdt., Eur.:—Pass. to be or become red, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: φοινός
div1.sense: blood-red, Il.: blood-stained, murderous, Hhymn.

div1.head: φοιταλέος
div1.sense: roaming wildly about, Mosch.
act. driving madly about, maddening, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: φοιταλιώτης
div1.sense: of Bacchus, the roamer, Anth.

div1.head: φοιτάς
div1.sense: fem. adj. roaming madly, of Cassandra, Aesch.; of the Bacchantes, Eur.; φ. νόσος madness, frenzy, Soph.; φ. ἐμπορίη, of commerce by sea, Anth.;—also used with a neut. Subst., φοιτάσι πτεροῖς on wandering wings, Eur.

div1.head: φοιτάω
div1.sense: to go to and fro, up and down, to stalk or roam about, Hom., etc.; διὰ νηὸς φ. to keep going about the ship, Od.; horses at pasture, Hdt.; of hounds casting about for the scent, Xen.
to roam wildly about, Hom., Soph.; of the priests of Cybele, Anth.

to resort to a person as a friend, φ. παρά τινα to visit him, Plat.; to resort constantly to a person or place for any purpose, ἐφοίτεον παρὰ Δηιόκεα δικασόμενοι Hdt.; φ. ἔς τε ἀγορὴν καὶ ἐξ ἀγορῆς Hdt.; φ. πρὸς τοὺς Ἀθηναίους, of embassies, Thuc.; φοιτᾶν ἐπὶ τὰς θύρας τινός to frequent, wait at a great manʼs door, Hdt.:—so, of a dream, to haunt one, ἐν ὀνείρασι Eur., Plat.
to resort to a person as a teacher, παρὰ τὸν Σωκράτη Plat.; παῖς ὢν ἐφοίτας ἐς τίνος διδασκάλου οἶκον; Ar.; absol. to go to school, Plat., Dem.

of things, to come in regularly, be imported, ἐξ ἐσχάτης γῆς ὅτε κασσίτερος ἡμῖν φοιτᾷ καὶ τὸ ἤλεκτρον Hdt.; σῖτός σφισι πολλὸς ἐφοίτα corn came in to them in plenty, Hdt.: —also, of the coming in of tribute or taxes, Lat. redire, τάλαντον ἀργυρίου Ἀλεξάνδρῳ ἡμέρης ἑκάστης ἐφοίτα a talent of silver came in to Alexander every day, Hdt.
of fits of pain, ἥδε νόσος ὀξεῖα φοιτᾷ καὶ ταχεῖʼ ἀπέρχεται Soph.

div1.head: φοίτησις
div1.sense: a constant going, mostly in pl., Xen.: esp. a going to school, Plat.

div1.head: φοιτητής
div1.sense: a scholar, pupil, Plat.

div1.head: φοῖτος
div1.sense: a constant going or coming:—metaph. wandering of mind, Aesch.

div1.head: φολκός
div1.sense: found only in Il., as epith. of Thersites, prob. bandy-legged, Lat. valgus.

div1.head: φόλλις
div1.sense: the Lat. follis, bellows, Anth.

div1.head: φόναξ
div1.sense: eager for blood, Xen.

div1.head: φονάω
div1.sense: Desiderative, to be athirst for blood, to be murderous, Soph.; part. pl. dat. fem. φονώσαις Soph.

div1.head: φόνευμα
div1.sense: that which is destined for slaughter, Eur.

div1.head: φονεύς
div1.sense: a murderer, slayer, homicide, Hom., Hdt., Attic; of the sword on which Ajax had thrown himself, Soph.:—also as fem., a murderess, Eur.; as adj., φονέα χεῖρα murdering hand, Eur.

div1.head: φονεύω
div1.sense: to murder, kill, slay, Hdt., Aesch., etc.: —Pass. to be slain, Eur., Thuc.

div1.head: φονή
div1.sense: slaughter, murder, always in pl., Il.; ἐν τῇσι φονῇσιν εἶναι to be in the act of slaying, Hdt.; ἐν φοναῖς πεσών Aesch.; σπᾶν φοναῖς to rend murderously, Soph.; ἄπεστιν ἐν φοναῖς θηροκτόνοις he is absent a-killing game, Eur.

div1.head: φονικός
div1.sense: inclined to slay, murderous, bloody, sanguinary, Thuc., Plat.
of murder or homicide, φ. δίκαι trials for homicide, Arist.; φ. νόμοι laws respecting homicide, Dem.; τὰ φ. murderous acts, murder, homicide, Isocr.

div1.head: φόνιος
div1.sense: of blood, bloody, Aesch., Eur.
bloody, bloodstained, blood-reeking, murderous, Trag.:—neut. pl. as adv., φόνια δερκόμενος Ar.
of actions, etc., bloody, murderous, deadly, Eur. Cf. φοίνιος.

div1.head: φονολιβής
div1.sense: blood-dripping, blood-reeking, Aesch.

div1.head: φονόρυτος
div1.sense: blood-reeking, Aesch.

div1.head: φόνος
div1.sense: murder, homicide, slaughter, Hom., Hes., etc.; φ. Ἑλληνικός a slaughter of Greeks, Hdt.: in pl., φόνοι τʼ ἀνδροκτασίαι τε Od.; φόνοι, στάσεις, ἔρις, μάχαι Soph.
in law, murder, homicide, φόνου διώκειν τινά to prosecute one for murder, Antipho.; φ. ἑκούσιος and ἀκούσιος murder and manslaughter, Dem.
blood shed in murder, gore, ἂμ φόνον, ἂν νέκυας Il.; also, ἐρυγόμενοι φόνον αἵματος clots of blood, Aesch., etc.
div1.etym: = φόνιον αἷμα, Aesch.; ἐμοῦσα θρόμβους φόνου vomiting
div1.sense: a corpse, τὸν Ἑλένας φόνον Eur.
of the agent of slaughter, φόνον ἔμμεναι ἡρώεσσι to be a death to heroes, Il.; φόνος γενέσθαι τινί Od.

div1.head: φοξός
div1.sense: pointed, epith. of Thersites, φοξὸς κεφαλήν peaked in head, having a sugar-loaf head, Il.

div1.head: φοράδην
div1.sense: adv. borne along, borne or carried in a litter, or the like, as a sick person, Eur. Dem.
with rushing motion, violently, Soph.

div1.head: φορά
div1.sense: a carrying, Soph.; ψήφου φ. the giving oneʼs vote, voting, Eur.
a bringing in of money, payment, Thuc., Xen.
a bringing forth, productiveness, Plat.
(from Pass. φέρομαι) a being borne or carried along, motion, movement, ἡ τῶν ἄστρων φορά Plat.
rapid motion, a rush, Lat. impetus, Dem.
(also from Pass.) that which is borne, a load, freight, burden, Plut.
that which is brought in or paid as rent or tribute, Thuc., Xen., etc.
that which is brought forth, fruit, produce, a crop, Arist.:—metaph., φορὰ προδοτῶν a large crop of traitors, Dem.

div1.head: φορβάς
div1.sense: giving pasture or food, feeding, Soph.
in the pasture, out at grass, grazing with the herd, Eur.

div1.head: φορβειά
div1.sense: a feeding-string, i. e. the halter by which a horse is tied to the manger, Xen.
a mouthband of leather put like a halter round the lips of pipers, to assist them in blowing, Ar.

div1.head: φορβή
div1.sense: pasture, food, fodder, forage, Il., Hdt.; of birds of prey, Soph.

div1.head: φορεῖον
div1.sense: a litter, Lat. lecti_ca, Dinarch.

div1.head: φορεύς
div1.sense: a bearer, carrier, Il.: ἵππος φορεύς a pack- horse, Plut.

div1.head: φορέω
div1.sense: to bear or carry constantly, to be used to carry, ἵπποι οἳ φορέεσκον Πηλείωνα Il.; of a slave, ὕδωρ ἐφόρει Od.; so, ἀγγελίας φορέειν to serve as a messenger (ἀγγελίην φέρειν simply to carry a message), Hdt.; φ. θρεπτήρια, of Oedipus carrying about food in a wallet, Soph.
commonly of clothes and armour, to bear constantly, wear, Lat. gesto, Hom., etc.
to have, possess, ἀγλαΐας φορέειν to be splendid, Od.; ἰσχυρὰς φ. τὰς κεφαλάς Hdt.; ὑπόπτερον δέμας φ. Eur.
Pass. to be borne violently along, be hurried along, Trag.; to be storm-tost, Ar.; to be carried away, Thuc.
Mid. to fetch for oneself, fetch regularly, Eur. Hence

div1.head: φορηδόν
div1.sense: bearing like a bundle, Luc.

div1.head: φόρημα
div1.sense: that which is carried, a load, freight, Lat. gestamen, Soph., Xen.
that which is worn, an ornament, Plut., etc.
as translation of Lat. ferculum, Plut.

div1.head: φορητός
div1.sense: borne, carried, Pind.
to be borne, endurable, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: φόριμος
div1.sense: bearing, fruitful, Anth.

div1.head: Φορκίδες
div1.sense: the daughters of Phorcys, the three Gorgons, Stheino, Euryale, Medu_sa, Pind., Aesch.

div1.head: Φόρκυς
div1.sense: Phorcys, a sea-god, father of the Graiae and Gorgons, Hes.: gen. also Φόρκῡνος (as if from Φόρκυν) ) , Od.

div1.head: φορμηδόν
div1.sense: like mat-work, cross-wise, athwart, Thuc.

div1.head: φόρμιγξ
div1.sense: the phorminx, a kind of lyre or harp, the oldest stringed instrument of the Greeks, esp. as the instrument of Apollo, Hom.; with seven strings (after Terpanderʼs time), Pind.
div1.etym: Commonly referred to φέρω, as if it were the portable lyre: better perh. from Root .φρεμ, Lat. fremo, to sound.

div1.head: φορμίζω
div1.sense: to play the φόρμιγξ, Hom.

div1.head: φορμικτής
div1.sense: a harper, Pind., Ar.

div1.head: φορμορραφέομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be stitched like a mat, to be hampered, a word of Demosth. ridiculed by Aeschin.

div1.head: φορμός
div1.sense: a basket for carrying corn, Hes., Hdt.
a mat, Lat. storea, Hdt., Ar.
a seamanʼs cloak, of coarse plaited stuff, Theocr.
a corn measure, Lys.

div1.head: φορολογέω
div1.sense: to levy tribute from, Polyb., Plut.

div1.head: φορολόγος
div1.sense: levying tribute, Plut.

div1.head: φορός
div1.sense: bringing on oneʼs way, forwarding, of a wind, favourable, Polyb., etc.
bringing in, productive, Theophr.

div1.head: φόρος
div1.sense: that which is brought in, tribute, such as is paid by subjects to a ruling state, as by the Asiatic Greeks to Athens, Thuc.; φόρου ὑποτελεῖς subject to pay tribute, Thuc.; φόρον ὑποτελέειν to pay tribute, Hdt.; ἀπάγειν, φέρειν Ar.; φ. τάξασθαι toagree to pay it, Hdt.; τάξαι to impose it, Dem.
any payment, Xen., Plut.

div1.head: φορτηγέω
div1.sense: to carry freights or loads in ships, Hdt.

div1.head: φορτηγία
div1.sense: a carrying of loads, carrying trade, Arist.

div1.head: φορτηγικός
div1.sense: of or for carrying loads, πλοῖον φ. a ship of burden, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: φορτηγός
div1.sense: one who carries burdens, a carrier, trafficker, merchant, Theogn., Polyb.

div1.head: φορτίζω
div1.sense: to load, Babr.; φορτίον φ. τινά to load one with a burden, NTest.:—Mid., τὰ μείονα φορτίζεσθαι to ship the smaller part of oneʼs wealth, Hes.—Pass. to be heavy laden, perf. part. πεφορτισμένος NTest., Luc.

div1.head: φορτικός
div1.sense: of the nature of a burden: metaph. (cf. φόρτος II) burdensome, wearisome, Dem., Luc.

coarse, vulgar, common, Ar., Plat.; of arguments, low, vulgar, ad captandum vulgus, Plat.; τοῦ φορτικοῦ ἕνεκα out of vulgar arrogance, Aeschin.: —adv. φορτικῶς, coarsely, vulgarly, like a clown, Plat., etc.

div1.head: φορτίον
div1.sense: a load, burden, Ar., Xen.
a shipʼs freight or lading, Lycurg.: in pl. wares, merchandise, Hes., Hdt., Attic
of a child in the womb, Xen.
metaph., φ. ἄρασθαι to take a heavy burden upon one, Dem.

div1.head: φορτίς
div1.sense: like ναῦς φορτηγός, a ship of burden, merchantman, Od.

div1.head: φόρτος
div1.sense: a load, a shipʼs freight or cargo, Od., Hes., etc.
metaph. a heavy load or burden, φ. χρείας, κακῶν Eur.
in Attic tiresome stuff, something common, low, coarse, vulgar, Ar.

div1.head: φορύνω
div1.sense: to be spoiled, defiled, Od.

div1.head: φορύσσω
div1.sense: to defile, Od.

div1.head: φορυτός
div1.sense: whatever is swept along by the wind, and so (like συρφετός, from σύρω), rubbish, sweepings, chaff, Ar.

div1.head: φόωσδε
div1.sense: to the light, to the light of day, Il.

div1.head: φόως
div1.etym: Epic lengthd. from φῶς, which is itself contr. from φάος
div1.sense: light, Hom., only in nom. and acc. sg.;

div0.div1: φράγδην as a defence, defensively, Batr. 266[LSJ supp.]

div1.head: φραγέλλιον
div1.sense: Lat. flagellum, a scourge, NTest.

div1.head: φραγελλόω
div1.sense: Lat. flagello, to scourge, NTest.

div1.head: φράγμα
div1.sense: a fence, breast-work, screen, Hdt., Plat.
generally a defence, φρ. μετώπων of a stagʼs horns, Anth.

div1.head: φραγμός
div1.sense: a fencing in, blocking up, Soph.
like φράγμα, a fence, paling, palisade, Hdt.
a place fenced off, an enclosure, Anth.
metaph. a partition, NTest.

div1.head: φραδάζω
div1.sense: to make known, γᾶν φράδασσε (poet. aor1) Pind.

div1.head: φραδή
div1.sense: understanding, knowledge, Pind.
a hint, warning, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: φραδής
div1.sense: understanding, wise, shrewd, opp. to ἀφραδής, Il.

div1.head: φραδμοσύνη
div1.sense: poet. Noun, understanding, shrewdness, cunning, in dat. pl. φραδμοσύνῃσιν Hhymn., Hes.

div1.head: φράζω
div1.sense: to point out, shew, indicate, Hom.; μῦθον πέφραδε πᾶσιν make known the word to all, Od.; ἔφρασε τὴν ἀτραπόν Hdt.; φωνῆσαι μὲν οὐκ εἶχε, τῆι δὲ χειρὶ ἔφραζε Hdt.
to shew forth, tell, declare, Hdt., Attic: c. gen. to tell of, Soph., etc.:—it differs from λέγω, as telling, declaring from simply speaking.
c. dat. pers. et inf. to tell one to do so and so, Hom., Thuc.
absol. to give counsel, advise, Soph., Aeschin.
Mid. and Pass. to indicate to oneself, i. e. to think or muse upon, consider, ponder, debate, Hom., etc.; ἐνὶ φρεσὶ μῆτιν ἀμείνω Il.; ἀμφὶς φρ. to think differently, Il.
to think of, purpose, contrive, devise, design, φ. τινι θάνατον Hom.; φράσσεται ὥς κε νέηται will contrive how . . , Od.
c. acc. et inf. to think, suppose, believe, imagine that . . , Od., Hdt.
to remark, perceive, observe, Hom.; c. gen., like αἰσθάνομαι Theocr.
to watch, guard, Od.:— to beware of, Orac. ap. Hdt.; φράζευ κύνα cave canem, Ar.;—c. inf., φράζου μὴ φωνεῖν take heed not to speak, Soph.:—so absol. to take heed, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: φράσις
div1.sense: speech; enunciation, Plut.

div1.head: φράσσω
div1.sense: to fence in, hedge round, esp. for protection or defence, to fence, secure, fortify, φράξε τὴν σχεδίην ῥίπεσσι he fenced the raft with mats, Od.:—Mid., φράξαντο νῆας they fenced in their ships, Il.; φραξάμενοι τὴν ἀκρόπολιν Hdt.; but, ἐφράξαντο τὸ τεῖχος they strengthened it, Hdt.; absol. to strengthen oneʼs fortifications, Thuc.:—Pass., φραχθέντες σάκεσιν fenced with shields, Il.; absol., πεφραγμένοι fenced, fortified, prepared for defence, Hdt., Thuc.
to put up as a fence, φράξαντες δόρυ δουρί, σάκος σάκεϊ joining spear close to spear, shield to shield (so as to make a fence), Il.; φράξαντες τὰ γέρρα having put up the shields as a fence, Hdt.
in Xen., of dogs, to put down the tail.
to stop up, block, τὴν ὁδόν Hdt.; τοὺς ἔσπλους Thuc.
metaph. to bar, stop: Pass., ἵνα πᾶν στόμα φραγῆι NTest.

div1.head: φράτηρ
div1.note: φρά_τηρ, gen. φράτερος, or φράτωρ, φράτορος, ὁ,
div1.sense: a member of a φράτρα· in pl. those of the same φράτρα, clansmen, Aesch., Ar.; εἰσάγειν τὸν υἱὸν εἰς τοὺς φράτερας (which was done when the boy came of age) Ar.; ἐγγράφειν τινὰ εἰς τοὺς φρ. Isae.; οὐκ ἔφυσε φράτερας (v. φραστήρ), he has not cut his citizen teeth, is no true citizen, Ar.; φράτερες τριωβόλου clansmen of the dicastʼs fee, Ar.

div1.head: φράτρα
div1.sense: a brotherhood: in Hom. a people of kindred race, a tribe, clan, κρῖνʼ ἄνδρας κατὰ φρήτρας, ὡς φρήτρη φρήτρῃφιν ἀρήγῃ choose men by clans, that clan may stand by clan, Il.

at Athens, the φρατρία was a subdivision of the φυλή, as at Rome the curia of the tribus, Isocr., etc.: every φυλή consisted of three φρατρίαι, whose members were called φράτερες or φράτορες (as those of a φυλή were φυλέται) : every φρατρία contained 30 γένη, so that by Solon.ʼs constitution Athens had 12 φρατρίαι, and 360 γένη or old patrician houses.
div1.etym: From the same Root as Lat. frater.

div1.head: φρατριάζω
div1.sense: to be in the same φρατρία, Dem.

div1.head: φρατρίαρχος
div1.sense: president of a φρατρία, Dem.

div1.head: φράτριος
div1.sense: of or belonging to a φράτρα· at Athens, epith. of Zeus and Athena, as tutelary deities of the phratriae, Plat., Dem.

div1.head: φρέαρ
div1.sense: a well (distinguished from κρήνη, a spring), Il., Hdt.
a tank, cistern, reservoir, Lat. puteus, Hdt., Thuc.: an oil jar, Ar.

div1.head: φρεατία
div1.sense: a tank or reservoir, Xen.

div1.head: φρεατίας
div1.sense: leading to a tank or reservoir, Xen.

div1.head: Φρεαττώ
div1.sense: a court in Peiraeeus, where homicides used to present themselves for trial, only in dat., ἐν Φρεαττοῖ Dem., Arist.

div1.head: φρεναπατάω
div1.sense: to deceive, NTest.

div1.head: φρεναπάτης
div1.sense: a soul-deceiver, NTest.

div1.head: φρενήρης
div1.sense: master of his mind, sound of mind, Lat. compos mentis, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: φρενιτιάω
div1.sense: to have a violent fever, be delirious or frantic, Plut.

div1.head: φρενοβλάβεια
div1.sense: damage of the understanding, madness, folly, Luc.

div1.head: φρενοβλαβής
div1.sense: damaged in the understanding, deranged, Lat. mente captus, Hdt.

div1.head: φρενογηθής
div1.sense: heart-gladdening, Anth.

div1.head: φρενοδαλής
div1.sense: ruining the mind, Aesch.

div1.head: φρενόθεν
div1.sense: of or from oneʼs own mind, Soph.

div1.head: φρενοκλόπος
div1.sense: stealing the understanding, deceiving, Anth.

div1.head: φρενολῃστής
div1.sense: a robber of the understanding, a deceiver, Anth.

div1.head: φρενομανής
div1.sense: distracting the mind, maddening, Aesch.

div1.head: φρενομόρως
div1.sense: so as to destroy the mind, Soph.

div1.head: φρενοπληγής
div1.sense: striking the mind, i. e. driving mad, maddening, Aesch.

div1.head: φρενόπληκτος
div1.sense: stricken in mind, frenzy-stricken, Aesch.

div1.head: φρενοτέκτων
div1.sense: building with the mind, ingenious, Ar.

div1.head: φρενόω
div1.sense: to make wise, instruct, inform, teach, τινά Trag., Xen.; φρενώσω δʼ οὐκέτʼ ἐξ αἰνιγμάτων, i. e. will teach plainly, Aesch.
in Pass. to be elated, Babr.

div1.head: φρενώλης
div1.sense: distraught in mind, frenzied, Aesch.

div1.head: φρέω
div1.etym: found only in the compds. διαφρέω, ἐκφρέω, εἰσφρέω, ἐπεισφρέω.

div1.head: φρήν
div1.sense: properly = διάφραγμα, the midriff or muscle which parts the heart and lungs (viscera thoracis) from the lower viscera (abdominis), Aesch.; usually in pl., Arist., etc.
in Hom., φρήν or φρένες the parts about the heart, the breast, Lat. praecordia, Il.; φρένες ἀμφιμέλαιναι Il.
the heart, as the seat of the passions, Hom., etc.; ἐκ φρενός from oneʼs very heart, Aesch.; φῦσαι φρένας to produce a haughty spirit, Soph.

the heart or mind, as the seat of thought, φρενὶ νοεῖν, ἐπίστασθαι Il., etc.; μετὰ φρεσὶ μερμηρίζειν Od.; κατὰ φρένα εἰδέναι, γνῶναι Il., etc.; κατὰ φρένα καὶ κατὰ θυμόν, as in Lat. mens animusque, Il.;—hence men lose their φρένες, i. e. their wits, Od.; πλήγη φρένας ἃς πάρος εἶχεν Il.;—so, in Attic, φρενῶν ἀφεστάναι, ἐκστῆναι to be out of oneʼs wits, Soph., Eur.; ποῦ ποτʼ εἰ φρενῶν; satisne sanus es? Soph.; φρενῶν ἐπήβολος in possession of oneʼs senses, Soph.; ἔνδον φρενῶν Eur.; ἐξ ἄκρας φρενός, i. e. superficially, Aesch.
of beasts, Il.
will, purpose, Soph.

div1.head: φρικαλέος
div1.sense: shivering with cold: horrid, Anth.

div1.head: φρίκη
div1.sense: a shuddering, shivering, Plat.
shuddering, esp. from religious awe, Hdt., Soph.

div1.head: φρικτός
div1.sense: to be shuddered at, horrible, Plut.

div1.head: φρικώδης
div1.sense: that causes shuddering, horrible, Eur., Ar.:—neut. φρικῶδες, as adv. horribly, Eur.:— adv. -δῶς, Sup., φρικωδέστατα ἔχειν to be in utter horror, Dem.

div1.head: φριμάσσομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to snort and leap about, to neigh and prance, of horses, Hdt.; of goats, Theocr. (Perh. formed from the sound.)

div1.head: φριξοκόμης
div1.sense: with bristling hair, Anth.

div1.head: φρίξ
div1.sense: the ruffling of a smooth surface: the ripple caused by a gust of wind over the smooth sea, Lat. horror, Od.
a bristling up, of the hair, Babr.

div1.head: φρίσσω
div1.sense: to be rough or uneven on the surface, to bristle, Lat. horrere, of a corn-field, Il., Eur.; of a line of battle, Il.; of hair or bristles, to bristle up, stand on end, Hes., Theocr.;—c. acc. cogn., φρίσσειν λοφιήν to set up his bristly mane, Od.; φρ. νῶτον Il.; χαίτην Ar.
φρίσσοντες ὄμβροι, like Virgilʼs horrida grando, Pind.
ἄσθματι φρίσσων πνοάς ruckling in his throat, of one just dying, Pind.
of a feeling of chill, when oneʼs skin contracts and forms what we call goose-skin, or when the hair stands up on end:
of the effect of cold, to shiver, Hes.

of the effect of fear, to shiver, shudder, Aesch., Soph.: c. acc. to shudder at one, Il., Soph.; πέφρικα Ἐρινὺν τελέσαι I tremble at the thought of her accomplishing, Aesch.;—so c. dat., ἐρετμοῖς φρίξουσιν they shall shudder at the oars, Orac. ap. Hdt.:—also c. part., πέφρικα λεύσσων I shudder at seeing, Aesch.; and c. inf. to fear to do, Dem.
to thrill with passionate joy, Soph.

div1.head: φροίμιον
div1.etym: contr. for προοίμιον, as φροῦδος for πρὸ ὁδοῦ.

div1.head: φρονέω
div1.sense: to think, to have understanding, to be sage, wise, prudent, ἄριστοι μάχεσθαί τε φρονέειν τε best both in battle and counsel, Il.; τὸ μὴ φρονοῦν, of an infant, Aesch.; οἱ φρονοῦντες the wise, Soph.; τὸ φρονεῖν φρόνησις, wisdom, understanding, Soph.:—with Advs., εὖ φρονεῖν Hdt., Trag.; καλῶς φρ. Od., etc.

to be minded in a certain way, to mean, intend, purpose, c. inf., Il.; φρόνεον ἰέναι were minded to go, Il.:—absol., φρονῶν ἔπρασσον prudens faciebam, purposely, Soph.; τοῦτο φρονεῖ ἡ ἀγωγὴ ἡμῶν this is what your bringing us here means, Thuc.

with a neut. adj., φρ. τινί τι to be so and so minded towards him, πατρὶ φίλα φρονέων kindly minded towards him, Hom.; so, κακὰ φρονέουσι ἀλλήλοισιν Il.; so with Advs., εὖ φρονεῖν τινι (v. supr.) Od., etc.

without a dat., ἀγαθά or κακὰ φρ. Hom.; πυκνά or πυκινὰ φρ. to have wise thoughts, be cunningly minded, Od.; ἐφημέρια φρ. to think only of the passing day, Od.; θνητὰ φρ. Eur.; τυραννικὰ φρ. to have tyranny in mind, Ar.; ἀρχαϊκὰ φρ. to have old-fashioned notions, Ar.; esp., μέγα φρονεῖν to be high-minded, Il., Soph., etc.; in bad sense, to be presumptuous, conceited, pride oneself, ἐπί τινι on a thing, Plat., etc.; ἐφʼ ἑαυτῷ μέγα φρ. Thuc.; φρ. μεῖζον ἢ κατʼ ἄνδρα to have thoughts too high for man, Soph.; σμικρὸν φρ. to be low- minded, poor- spirited, Soph.; ἦσσον, ἔλασσον φρ. Eur., etc.; οὐ σμικρὸν φρ. ἔς τινα Eur.
τά τινος φρονεῖν to be of his mind, of his party, side with him, Hdt., etc.; φρ. τὰ Βρασίδου Ar.; —so ἶσον ἐμοὶ φρονέουσα thinking like me, Il.; τὰ αὐτά, κατὰ τωὐτὸ φρ. to be like- minded, Hdt.
to have a thing in oneʼs mind, mind, take heed to a thing, Od., Aeschin., etc.

to be in possession of oneʼs senses, to be sensible, be alive, ἔτι φρονέοντα, for ἔτι ζῶντα, Il.; ἐν τῷ φρονεῖν γὰρ μηδὲν ἥδιστος βίος Soph.:—also to be in oneʼs senses, Soph.; φρονῶν οὐδὲν φρονεῖς though in thy wits thouʼrt nothing wise, Eur.

div1.head: φρόνημα
div1.sense: oneʼs mind, spirit, Lat. animus, Aesch., Plat., etc.
thought, purpose, will, Soph.; pl. thoughts, Trag.
either in good or bad sense,
high feeling, highmindedness, high spirit, resolution, pride, Hdt., Aesch., etc.: pl. high thoughts, proud designs, Hdt., Plat.
in bad sense, presumption, arrogance, Aesch., Eur., etc.; and in pl., Isocr., Plut., etc.
pl. = φρένες, the heart, breast, Aesch.

div1.head: φρονηματίζομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to become presumptuous, Arist.

div1.head: φρονηματίας
div1.sense: self-confident, high-spirited, or (in bad sense) presumptuous, arrogant, Xen., Arist.

div1.head: φρόνησις
div1.sense: a minding to do so and so, purpose, intention, Soph.
arrogance, Eur.
thoughtfulness, prudence, Plat., etc.

div1.head: φρονητέος
div1.sense: one must think: μέγα φρ. one must pride oneself, Xen.

div1.head: φρόνιμος
div1.sense: in oneʼs right mind, in oneʼs senses, Soph.
staid, unmoved, discreet, Xen.; τὸ φρ. presence of mind, Xen.
wise, sensible, prudent, Lat. prudens, Plat., etc.:— τὸ φρόνιμον prudence, Plat.; and in pl., ἄπορος ἐπὶ φρόνιμα devoid of wisdom, Soph.; φρονιμώτατα λέγειν Xen.
adv. -μως, Ar., Plat., etc.; φρ. ἔχειν Xen.; comp. φρονιμώτερον, Isocr.

div1.head: φρόνις
div1.sense: prudence, wisdom, περίοιδε δίκας ἠδὲ φρόνιν ἄλλων [Nestor] knows well the customs and wisdom of other men, Od.; κατὰ φρόνιν ἤγαγε πολλήν he brought back much wisdom from Troy, Od.

div1.head: φρονούντως
div1.etym: adverb from pres. act. part. of φρονέω
div1.sense: wisely, prudently, Soph.

div1.head: φροντίζω
div1.sense: absol. to think, consider, reflect, take thought, have a care, give heed, Theogn., Hdt., Attic: to be thoughtful or anxious, πεφροντικὸς βλέπειν to look thoughtful, Eur.
with an object,

c. acc. rei, to think of, consider, to think out, devise, contrive, Hdt., Attic; foll. by relat. clause, the Verb being in fut., φ. τοῦτο, ὅκως μὴ λείψομαι Hdt.; φρ. πρὸς ἑωυτὸν ὡς δώσει Hdt.; φρ. ὅπως . . to take thought or consider how a thing shall be done, Plat.

c. gen. to take thought for, give heed to a thing, care about it, regard it, mostly with a negat., Περσέων οὐδὲν φρ. Hdt.; Πενθέως οὐ φροντίσας Eur.; οὐδὲ τῶν νόμων φροντίζουσι Plat.;—so with Advs. implying a negat., σμικρὸν φρ. Σωκράτους Plat.:—so also, with a prep., φρ. περί τινος to be concerned or anxious about a thing, Hdt., Xen.:— μὴ φροντίσῃς heed it not, Ar.; οὐ, μὰ Δίʼ, οὐδʼ ἐφρόντισα Ar.

div1.head: φρόντισμα
div1.sense: that which is thought out, a thought, invention, Ar.

div1.head: φροντίς
div1.sense: thought, care, heed, attention bestowed upon a person or thing, c. gen., φροντίδʼ ἔχειν τινός Eur.; ἐν φροντίδι εἶναι περί τινος Hdt.

absol. thought, meditation, Aesch., Soph.; ἐν φροντίδι μοι ἐγένετο τὸ πρῆγμα Hdt.; ἐμβῆσαί τινα ἐς φροντίδα to set one a thinking, Hdt., etc.:—in pl. thoughts, αἱ δεύτεραί πως φροντίδες σοφώτεραι Eur.
deep thought, care, concern, Aesch.; οὐ φροντὶς Ἱπποκλείδῃ no matter to Hippocleides! Hdt.

div1.head: φροντιστέος
div1.sense: one must take heed, Eur., Plat.

div1.head: φροντιστήριον
div1.sense: a place for meditation, a thinking shop, school, Ar., Luc.

div1.head: φροντιστής
div1.sense: a deep, hard thinker, as Socrates is called in derision by Ar.; so, φρ. τῶν μετεώρων, τῶν οὐρανίων a thinker on supra-terrestrial things, Xen.; μετέωρα φρ. Plat.

div1.head: φροντιστικός
div1.sense: thoughtful, Luc.:—adv. -κῶς, Xen.

div1.head: φροῦδος
div1.etym: contr. from πρὸ ὁδοῦ, as φροίμιον from προοίμιον
div1.sense: gone away, clean gone, (as Hom. says πρὸ ὁδοῦ ἐγένοντο) :
of persons, gone, fled, departed, Soph., etc.; c. part., φροῦδοί εἰσι διώκοντές σε they are gone in pursuit, Soph.; of the dead, φρ. αὐτὸς εἶ θανών thou art dead and gone, Soph., Eur.
undone, ruined, helpless, Eur.
of things, gone, vanished, Soph., Eur.; φρούδη μὲν αὐδή, φροῦδα δʼ ἄρθρα they are gone, i. e. refuse their office, Eur.

div1.head: φρουρά
div1.sense: a looking out, watch, guard, as a duty, Hdt., Aesch.; φρουρὰν ἄζηλον ὀχήσω shall keep unenviable watch, Aesch.; φρουρὰ ὄμματος my watchful eye, Soph.; φρουρᾶς ᾄδειν to sing while on guard, Ar.
a prison, Plat.
of persons, a watch, guard, garrison, Hdt., Aesch., etc.; esp. of frontier-posts, which were guarded in Attica by the περίπολοι, Xen.
at Sparta, a body of men destined for service, φρουρὰν φαίνειν (v. φαίνω A. 1. 5).

div1.head: φρουραρχία
div1.sense: the office or post of φρούραρχος, place of commandant, Xen.

div1.head: φρούραρχος
div1.sense: commander of a watch or fortress, Xen.

div1.head: φρουρέω
div1.sense: to keep watch or guard, Hdt., Thuc.
trans. to watch, guard, Hdt., Trag., etc.; στόμα φρουρεῖν εὔφημον, i. e. to keep silent, Eur.:—Pass. to be watched or guarded, Hdt., Trag.
to watch for, Eur.; φρ. τὸ χρέος to observe oneʼs duty, Soph.
Mid., like φυλάσσομαι, to be on oneʼs guard against, beware of, c. acc., Eur.:—Act. in same sense, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: φρούρημα
div1.sense: that which is watched or guarded, λείας βουκόλων φρουρήματα the herdsmenʼs charge of cattle, Soph.
a guard, Aesch.; of a single man, Aesch.
watch, ward, φρούρημα ἔχειν Eur.

div1.head: φρουρητός
div1.sense: watched, guarded, Anth.

div1.head: φρουρήτωρ
div1.sense: a watcher, Anth.

div1.head: φρούριον
div1.sense: a watch-post, garrisoned fort, citadel, Aesch., Thuc., etc.
the guard, garrison, of a place, Aesch., Thuc.

div1.head: φρουρίς
div1.sense: a guard-ship, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: φρουροδόμος
div1.sense: watching the house, Anth.

div1.head: φρουρός
div1.sense: a watcher, guard, Eur., Thuc., etc.
div1.etym: Contr. for προουρός, as φροῦδος from πρὸ ὁδοῦ.

div1.head: φρύαγμα
div1.sense: a violent snorting, neighing, Aesch., Soph.
metaph. wanton behaviour, insolence, Anth.

div1.head: φρυαγματίας
div1.sense: a hot-tempered horse: metaph. as adj. arrogant, wanton, Plut.

div1.head: φρυαγμοσέμνακος
div1.sense: wanton and haughty, Ar.

div1.head: φρυάσσομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:—of spirited horses, to neigh and prance, Anth.; φρ. πρὸς τοὺς ἀγῶνας to neigh eagerly for the race, Plut.
metaph. of men, to be wanton, unruly, Anth.:—so in aor1 act. ἐφρύαξα, NTest.

div1.head: φρυγανισμός
div1.sense: a gathering of dry sticks for fuel, a collecting firewood, Thuc.

div1.head: φρύγανον
div1.sense: mostly in pl. dry sticks, firewood, Lat. sarmenta, Hdt., Ar., etc.:—the sg. only in collective sense = τὰ φρύγανα, Ar.

div1.head: φρυγίλος
div1.sense: a bird, perh. a finch, Lat. fringilla, Ar.

div1.head: Φρύγιος
div1.sense: Phrygian, of, from Phrygia, Eur.
Φρ. νόμοι, μέλη Phrygian music, i. e. music played on the flute, wilder than the music for the lyre, Eur. Hence

div1.head: Φρυγιστί
div1.sense: in the Phrygian mode, Plat.

div1.head: φρύγω
div1.sense: to roast or fry, Ar.; ἐρετμοῖσι φρύξουσι they shall cook with the [wood of] the oars, Orac. ap. Hdt.:—Pass., πεφρυγμέναι κριθαί roasted barley, Thuc.
of the sun, to parch, Lat. torrere, Theocr.

div1.head: φρυκτός
div1.sense: roasted, Ar.
as Subst., φρυκτός, οῦ, a signal-fire, bale-fire, beacon, Aesch.; φρυκτοὶ πολέμιοι αἴρονται ἐς τόπον fire-signals of an enemyʼs approach are made to a place, Thuc.

div1.head: φρυκτωρέω
div1.sense: to give signals by fire:—Pass., ἐφρυκτωρήθησαν νῆες προσπλέουσαι the approach of ships was signalled by beacon-fires, Thuc.

div1.head: φρυκτωρία
div1.sense: a giving signals by beacons or alarm fires, telegraphing, Aesch., Ar.

div1.head: φρυκτώριον
div1.sense: a beacon-tower, light-house, Plut.

div1.head: φρυκτωρός
div1.sense: a fire-watch, i. e. one who watches to give signals by beacon-fires, Aesch., Thuc.

div1.head: φρύνη
div1.sense: a toad, Arist.

div1.head: Φρυνίχειος
div1.sense: of or like Phrynichus (the Com. Poet), τὸ Φρ. ἐκλακτίζειν Ar.

div1.head: φρῦνος
div1.sense: like φρύνη, a toad, Arist.

div1.head: Φρύξ
div1.sense: a Phrygian, Il.:—as the name of a slave, Ar.: cf. Davus, Geta.

div1.head: φύγαδε
div1.sense: like φόβονδε, to flight, to flee, φύγαδʼ ἔτραπεν ἵππους turned his horses to flight, Il.

div1.head: φυγαδεύω
div1.sense: to drive from a country, banish, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: φυγαδικός
div1.sense: of or for an exile, φ. προθυμία the reckless zeal of an exile, Thuc. adv. -κῶς, Plut.

div1.head: φυγαδοθήρας
div1.sense: one who hunts after runaways or exiles, Plut.

div1.head: φυγαίχμης
div1.sense: fleeing from the spear, unwarlike, cowardly, Aesch.

div1.head: φυγάς
div1.sense: one who flees from his country, a runaway, fugitive, a banished man, exile, refugee, Lat. exul, profugus, Hdt., Attic; φυγάδα ποιεῖν τινα Xen.; κατάγειν φυγάδας to recall them; etc.
of an army, put to flight, Soph.

div1.head: φυγγάνω
div1.etym: collat. form of φεύγω, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: φυγή
div1.sense: flight in battle, Lat. fuga, Od., Hdt., Trag.; dat. φυγῇ adverbially, in hasty flight, Soph., Eur.; φυγῇ φεύγειν Plat.
flight or escape from a thing, avoidance of it, c. gen., νόσων φυγαί Soph.; φυγαὶ λέκτρων Eur.
banishment, exile, Lat. exilium, Trag., Soph.; φυγὴν φεύγειν to go into banishment, Plat.; ζημιοῦν φυγῇ Eur.; φυγῆς τιμᾶσθαι (sc. δίκην) , to be awarded the penalty of exile, Plat.
as a collective Noun, = φυγάδες, a body of exiles or refugees, Thuc., Aeschin.

div1.head: φυγοδέμνιος
div1.sense: shunning the marriage-bed, Anth.

div1.head: φυγοδικέω
div1.sense: to shun, shirk a trial, Dem.

div1.head: φυγομαχέω
div1.sense: to shun battle or war, Polyb.

div1.head: φυγόμαχος
div1.sense: shunning battle, Simon.

div1.head: φυγόξενος
div1.sense: shunning strangers, inhospitable, Pind.

div1.head: φυγοπονία
div1.sense: aversion to work, Polyb.

div1.head: φυγόπονος
div1.sense: shunning work or hardship, Polyb.

div1.head: φυγοπτόλεμος
div1.sense: shunning war, cowardly, Od.

div1.head: φυζακινός
div1.sense: flying, runaway, shy, Il., Anth.

div1.head: φύζα
div1.sense: headlong flight, rout, Hom.

div1.head: φυή
div1.sense: growth, stature, esp. fine growth, noble stature, Hom.; Νέστορι εἶδός τε μέγεθός τε φυήν τʼ ἄγχιστα ἐῴκει he was like Nestor both in shape and size and stature (or growth), Il.
poet. for φύσις, oneʼs natural powers, nature, genius, Pind.
the flower or prime of age, Pind.

div1.head: φυκιόεις
div1.sense: full of sea-weed, weedy, Il., Theocr.

div1.head: φυκίον
div1.sense: = φῦκος 1, mostly used in pl., Plat., Theocr.
= φῦκος II, rouge, Luc.

div1.head: φυκογείτων
div1.sense: near the sea-weed, dwelling by the sea, Anth.

div1.head: φῦκος
div1.sense: Lat. fucus, sea-weed, sea-wrack, tangle, Il.
a red colour prepared from it, rouge, Lat. fucus, Ar., Theocr.

div1.head: φυκτός
div1.sense: to be shunned or escaped, avoidable, Hom.

div1.head: φυλάζω
div1.sense: fut. άξω, to divide into tribes, Plut.

div1.head: φυλακή
div1.sense: a watching or guarding, watch, guard, ward, esp. by night, φυλακῆς μνήσασθε keep watch and ward, Il.; so, φυλακὰς ἔχειν Il.; ὅπως ἀφανὴς εἴη ἡ φ. that there might be nothing visible to watch, Thuc.; φυλακὴν φυλάττειν to keep watch, Xen.; τὰς φ. ποιεῖσθαι Xen.; φυλακὰς καταστήσασθαι to set watches, Ar.
a watch or guard, of persons, Plat., Xen., etc.; ἡ τοῦ σώματος φ. a body guard, Dem.:— a guard or garrison, Hdt.; ἡ ἐν τῇ Ναυπάκτῳ φ., of a squadron of ships, Thuc.
of place, a watch, station, post, Il., Xen.
of time, a watch of the night, Hdt., Eur., etc.
a place for keeping others in, a ward, prison, Anth., NTest.

a watching, guarding, keeping, preserving, whether for security or custody, ἔχειν ἐν φυλακῇ τινά to keep guarded or occupied, Hdt.; τὸν τῆς γλώσσης χαρακτῆρα ἐν φυλακῇ ἔχειν to preserve the same character of language, Hdt.; so, διὰ φυλακῆς ἔχειν or ποιεῖσθαί τι, Thuc.:—also, φυλακὴν ἔχειν, φυλάττεσθαι, to keep guard, be on the watch, περί τινα Hdt.; ἦσαν ἐν φυλακῇσι were on their guard, Hdt.
guardianship, Arist.
a safe-guard, Isocr.
(from Mid.) precaution, Plat.

div1.head: φυλακικός
div1.sense: fitted for watching or guarding, watchful, careful, Plat.

div1.head: φυλακός
div1.etym: Epic and Ionic for φύλαξ, Il., Hdt.

div1.head: φυλακτέος
div1.sense: to be watched or kept, Soph., Eur.
φυλακτέον one must observe, obey, Eur.
(from Mid.) one must guard against, τι Aesch., Plat.

div1.head: φυλακτήριον
div1.sense: a guarded post, a fort or castle, Hdt.: an outpost, Lat. statio, Thuc., Xen.
a safe-guard, preservative, Dem.; among the Jews φυλακτήρια were strips of parchment with texts from the Law written on them, used as amulets, NTest.

div1.head: φυλακτικός
div1.sense: preservative, c. gen., Arist.
of persons, vigilant, observant, Xen.; φ. ἐγκλημάτων cherishing the recollection of them, Arist.
(from Mid.) cautious, Arist.

div1.head: φύλαξις
div1.sense: a security, Eur.

div1.head: φύλαξ
div1.sense: a watcher, guard, sentinel, Lat. excubitor, Hom., Attic; οἱ φ. the garrison, Thuc., Xen., etc.; φύλακες τοῦ σώματος body guards, Plat.;—also as fem., κλῇς ἐπὶ γλώσσῃ φ. Soph., Eur., etc.
a guardian, keeper, protector, Hes., etc.;—c. gen. objecti, φ. δορός a protector against it, the spear, Eur.
an observer, τοῦ δόγματος Plat.; τοῦ ἐπιταττομένου Xen.
of things, φύλακες ἐπὶ τοῖς ὠνίοις, of the ἀγορανόμοι, Lys.

div1.head: φυλαρχέω
div1.sense: to be or act as φύλαρχος, Xen.

div1.head: φυλαρχία
div1.sense: the office of φύλαρχος, Arist.

div1.head: φύλαρχος
div1.sense: the chief of a φῡλή, a phylarch, Hdt., Xen.:—used to transl. the Rom. tribunus, Plut.
at Athens, the commander of the cavalry furnished by each tribe, v. ἵππαρχος.

div1.head: Φυλάσιος
div1.sense: a man of Phyle (in Attica), Ar.

div1.head: φυλάσσω
div1.sense: absol. to keep watch and ward, keep guard, Hom., Attic; σὺν κυσὶ φυλάσσοντες περὶ μῆλα Il.

trans. to watch, guard, keep, defend, Hom., etc.; φυλάττειν τινὰ ἀπό τινος to guard one from a person or thing, Xen.:—also φ. τινὰ μὴ πάσχειν to guard one against suffering, Soph.:—Pass. to be watched, kept under guard, Hdt.

to watch for, lie in wait or ambush for, Hom., Thuc.; φ. τὸ σύμβολον to look out for the signal-fire, Aesch.: to watch, to wait for, observe an appointed time or a fixed event, Hdt., Thuc.; φ. νύκτα to wait for night, Thuc.

metaph. to keep, maintain, cherish, χόλον, ὅρκια Il.; φ. ἔπος to observe a command, Il.; νόμον Soph.; φ. σκαιοσύναν to cling to it, foster it, Soph.:—Pass., φυλάττεσθαι παρά τινι to be fostered in or by . . , Soph.
to keep or continue in a place, τόδε δῶμα φυλάσσοις Od.
Mid., with perf. pass.,
absol. to be on oneʼs guard, keep watch, νύκτα φυλασσομένοισι Il.; πεφυλαγμένος εἶναι to be cautious, prudent, Il.; so, φυλασσομένους πορεύεσθαι with caution, Xen.
c. acc. to keep a thing by one, bear it in mind, Hes., Soph.
to guard, keep safe, καὶ κεφαλὴν πεφύλαξο Orac. ap. Hdt.
c. inf. to take care to do, Hdt.
c. gen., φυλάσσεσθαι τῶν νεῶν to take care for the ships, be chary of them, Thuc.

φυλάσσεσθαί τι or τινα to beware of, be on oneʼs guard against, shun, avoid, Hdt., Aesch.; also φ. πρός τι Thuc.; ἀπό τινος Xen.;—c. part., εἰσορῶν φυλάξομαι I will take care to look on, Soph.;—c. inf., φ. μὴ ποιεῖν to take care not to do, guard against doing, Hdt.; φ. τὸ μὴ γενέσθαι τι Dem.; so, φ. μή or φ. ὅπως μὴ . . , with subj., to take care lest a thing happen, Eur., Xen.: rarely c. gen., τῶν εὖ φύλαξαι Soph.
sometimes Act. has sense of Mid., Eur., Plat.

div1.head: φυλετεύω
div1.sense: to adopt into a tribe, Arist.

div1.head: φυλέτης
div1.sense: one of the same tribe, a tribesman, Lat. tribulis, ὦ φυλέτα Ar.

div1.head: φυλετικός
div1.sense: of or for a φυλέτης, tribal, Arist.

div1.head: φυλή
div1.sense: like φῦλον, a race or tribe of men, κατὰ φυλάς Xen.
a body of men united by ties of blood and descent, a clan, such as those among the Dorians (φ. γενική) , Pind.; of the four old Attic Tribes, Hdt., Eur.; of the Jewish, NTest.

a tribe connected by local habitation, like our hundred or county, such as the ten local tribes at Athens formed by Cleisthenes (φ. τοπική) , Hdt., etc.—The subdivisions of the φυλαὶ γενικαί were φρατρίαι, those of the φυλαὶ τοπικαί were δῆμοι.
the contingent of soldiers furnished by a tribe, Hdt., Thuc., etc.:—later, a brigade of cavalry, Xen.; cf. φύλαρχος II.

div1.head: φυλία
div1.sense: a tree mentioned with the olive in Od.; either the wild olive, or the buck-thorn.

div1.head: φυλλάς
div1.sense: a heap of leaves, bed or litter of leaves, Hdt., Soph.
the leaves or foliage of a tree, Aesch.:— a branch or bough, Eur., Ar.
poet. for a tree or plant, φ. Παρνησία, i. e. the laurel, Eur.; φ. μυριόκαρπος, of a thick grove, Soph.

div1.head: φυλλεῖον
div1.sense: mostly in pl. green-stuff, small herbs, such as mint and parsley, Ar.

div1.head: φύλλινος
div1.sense: of or from leaves, made of leaves, Theocr., Luc.

div1.head: φυλλοβολέω
div1.sense: to shed the leaves, Ar.

div1.head: φυλλοβόλος
div1.sense: shedding leaves, Theophr.

div1.head: φυλλόκομος
div1.sense: thick-leaved, Ar.

div1.head: φύλλον
div1.sense: a leaf; in pl. leaves, or collectively the leaves, foliage of a tree, Hom., Hdt., etc.; οἵη περ φύλλων γενεή, τοίη δὲ καὶ ἀνδρῶν as is the generation of leaves, such is that of men, Il.; φύλλοις βάλλειν Eur.; in sg., φύλλον ἐλάας, poet. for ἐλάα, Soph.:—metaph. of choral songs, φύλλʼ ἀοιδᾶν Pind.
of flowers, a petal, Hdt., Theocr.
a medicinal herb, Soph.

div1.head: φυλλορροέω
div1.sense: to shed the leaves, in Com. phrase, φ. ἀσπίδα to shed or let drop oneʼs shield, Ar.

div1.head: φυλλόστρωτος
div1.sense: strewed or covered with leaves, Eur.:—also dat. φυλλοστρῶτι (as if from φυλλοστρώς), Theocr.

div1.head: φυλλοφόρος
div1.sense: bearing leaves, φ. ἀγών a contest in which the prize is a crown of leaves, Pind.

div1.head: φυλλοχοέω
div1.sense: to shed leaves or hair, Anth.

div1.head: φυλοκρινέω
div1.sense: to make distinctions of race, Thuc.

div1.head: φῦλον
div1.sense: a race, tribe, class of men, Hom., etc.; oft. in pl. hosts, swarms, also of other animals, swarms of gnats, Il.; φῦλον ὀρνίθων the race of birds, Soph.
a sex, Hes.; τὸ θῆλυ, τὸ ἄρρεν φ. Xen.
in closer sense, a race of people, a nation, φῦλα Πελασγῶν Il.; κελαινὸν φ., of the Aethiopians, Aesch., etc.
more closely still, = φυλή II. 1, a clan or tribe of men acc. to blood or descent, κατὰ φῦλα Il.

div1.head: φύλοπις
div1.sense: the battle-cry, din of battle, battle, Hom.

div1.head: φῦμα
div1.sense: like φυτόν, a growth: esp. a tumour, Hdt.

div1.head: φύξιμος
div1.sense: offering a chance of escape: neut. φύξιμον a place of escape, a place of refuge, Od.; ἱερὸν φ. an asylum, Plut.
c. acc., φύξιμός τινα able to flee from or escape one, Soph.

div1.head: φύξιον
div1.sense: like φύξιμον, a place of refuge, Plut.

div1.head: φῦ
div1.sense: fie! faugh! an exclamation of disgust, Ar.

div1.head: φύραμα
div1.sense: that which is mixed and kneaded, dough, NTest.

div1.head: φυράω
div1.sense: to mix flour or meal so as to make it into dough, to knead, Hdt., Xen.; γῆν φυράσειν φόνῳ to make earth into a bloody paste, Aesch.:—Pass., οἴνῳ καὶ ἐλαίῳ πεφυραμένα ἄλφιτα Thuc.
metaph., μαλακὴν φωνὴν φυράσασθαι to make up a soft voice, Ar.

div1.head: φύρδην
div1.sense: mixedly, in utter confusion, Aesch., Xen.; Doric φύρδαν, Anth.

div1.head: φύρω
div1.sense: to mix something dry with something wet, mostly with a sense of mixing so as to soil or defile, δάκρυσιν εἵματʼ ἔφυρον they wetted, sullied their garments with tears, Il.; also c. gen., χείλεα φύρσω αἵματος Od.:—Pass., δάκρυσι πεφυρμένη Il.; αἵματι οἶκος ἐφύρθη Aesch.
of dry things, κόνει φύρουσα κάρα Eur.; γαίαι πεφύρσεσθαι κόμαν to be doomed to have oneʼs hair defiled with earth, Pind.

metaph. to mingle together, confuse, ἔφυρον εἰκῆ πάντα they mixed all things up together, did all at random, Aesch., etc.:—Pass. to be mixed up, ἐκ πεφυρμένου καὶ θηριώδους from a confused and savage state, Eur.
in Pass. also to mix with others, have dealings with him, Plat.

div1.head: φῦσα
div1.sense: a pair of bellows, bellows, mostly in pl., Il., Thuc.; in sg., Hdt.
a wind, blast, wind in the stomach, in pl., Plat.
of fire, a stream or jet, Hhymn.
an air-bubble, Luc.

div1.head: φύσας
div1.sense: ὁ φύσας a father; cf. φύς.

div1.head: φυσάω
div1.sense: trans. to puff or blow up, distend, Ar., Xen.; of bag-pipers, Ar.; φ. τὰς γνάθους to puff them out, Dem.:—Pass. to be inflated, ἡ γαστὴρ ἐπεφύσητό μοι Ar.
metaph. to puff one up, make him vain, and so to cheat, Dem.:—Pass. to be puffed up, ἐπί τινι at a thing, Xen.
to blow up, kindle a fire: but also
to blow out, extinguish, τὴν λαμπάδα Ar.
to blow out, spurt out, Soph.
to blow a wind-instrument, Eur., Ar., Theocr.

div1.head: φύσημα
div1.sense: that which is blown or produced by blowing, φ. δύστλητον a hard-drawn breath, Eur.; δνοφώδη αἰθέρος φυσήματα, of stormy blasts, Eur.; πόντιον φ. the roaring or raging of the sea, Eur.; μέλανος αἵματος φυσήματα black blood blown from the nostrils, of newly slaughtered cattle, Eur.
a bubble, Luc.
a blowing, puffing, snorting, of a horse, Xen.: metaph. conceit, Plat.

div1.head: φυσητήρ
div1.sense: an instrument for blowing, blowpipe or tube, Hdt.

div1.head: φυσίαμα
div1.sense: a breathing hard, blowing, Aesch.

div1.head: φυσιάω
div1.sense: Epic part. φῡσιόων, intr. to blow, puff, breathe hard, pant, Il., Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: φυσιγγόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be excited by eating garlic, properly of fighting cocks: hence the Megarians (who were large growers of garlic) are said to be ὀδύναις πεφυσιγγωμένοι infuriated by vexations, Ar.

div1.head: φυσίγναθος
div1.sense: puff-cheek, name of a frog, Batr.

div1.head: φῦσιγξ
div1.sense: the stalk of garlic, or the outer coat of a clove of garlic.

div1.head: φυσίζοος
div1.sense: life-producing, Hom.

div1.head: φυσικός
div1.sense: natural, native, opp. to διδακτός, Xen., Arist.
of or in the order of nature, natural, physical, opp. to ἠθικός, Arist.

div1.head: φυσιογνωμονέω
div1.sense: to study features, judge a manʼs character by his features, Dem.

div1.head: φυσιογνώμων
div1.sense: judging of a manʼs character by his features, Arist.

div1.head: φυσιόω
div1.sense: to puff up, NTest.: (for Epic part. φυσιόων, v. φυσιάω).

div1.head: φύσις
div1.sense: the nature, natural qualities, powers, constitution, condition, of a person or thing, Od., Hdt., Attic
like φυή, form, stature, ἢ νόον ἤ τοι φύσιν either in mind or outward form, Pind.; τὸν δὲ Λάϊον, φύσιν τίνʼ εἶχε, φράζε Soph.; τὴν ἐμὴν ἰδὼν φύσιν Ar.
of the mind, oneʼs nature, natural bent, powers, character, Soph., etc.
often periphr., πέτρου φύσιν σύ γʼ ὀργάνειας, i. e. wouldʼst provoke a stone, Soph.; ἡ φ. αὐτοῦ for αὐτός, Plat.

nature, i. e. the order or law of nature, κατὰ φύσιν πεφυκέναι to be made so by nature, naturally, Hdt., etc.;—opp. to παρὰ φύσιν, Eur., Thuc.; so, προδότης ἐκ φύσεως a traitor by nature, Aeschin.:—so, in dat. φύσει, by nature, naturally, Ar., etc.:—φύσιν ἔχει, c. inf., it is natural that . . , Hdt., Plat.
origin, birth, φύσει γεγονότες εὖ Hdt.; φ. νεώτερος Soph.; so, τὴν φύσιν Xen.
nature, universe, Plat., Arist.

as a concrete term, creatures, animals (cf. φύστις) , θνητὴ φ. man kind, Soph.; πόντου εἰναλία φ. the creatures of the sea, Soph.; θήλεια φ. woman- kind, Xen.; οἱ τοιαῦται φύσεις such creatures as these, Isocr.
a nature, kind, sort, βιοτῆς φύσις Soph.: species, Xen.
sex, Soph., Thuc.

div1.head: φυσίωσις
div1.sense: a being puffed up, inflation, NTest.

div1.head: φύσκη
div1.sense: a sausage or black-pudding, Ar.

div1.head: φύς
div1.sense: ὁ φύς a son; cf. φύσας.

div1.head: φυστή
div1.sense: (sc. μᾶζα) , a kind of barley-cake, the dough being lightly mixed, not kneaded firmly, Anth.; φ. μᾶζα Ar.

div1.head: φύστις
div1.sense: a progeny, race, Aesch.

div1.head: φυταλιά
div1.sense: a planted place, an orchard or vineyard, opp. to corn-land (ἄρουρα) , Il.
a plant, Anth.
div1.etym: υ is made long in dactylic verses.

div1.head: φυτάλμιος
div1.sense: producing, nourishing, fostering, φυτάλμιοι γέροντες fostering sires or aged parents, Aesch.; λέκτρα φυτ. the marriage bed, Eur.
natural, by nature; Soph. O. C. 150 should be pointed thus: ἒ ἒ ἀλαῶν ὀμμάτων. ἆρα καὶ ἦσθα φυτάλμιος δυσαίων; woe for thy blind eyes! say wast thou thus miserable by nature, from thy birth?

div1.head: φυτεία
div1.sense: a planting, Xen.
the growth of a plant, Xen.
a plant, NTest.

div1.head: φύτευμα
div1.sense: a plant, Pind., Soph.

div1.head: φυτευτήριον
div1.sense: a plant grown in a nursery, Xen.
a nursery or plantation, Dem.

div1.head: φυτευτός
div1.sense: planted, produced, Plat.

div1.head: φυτεύω
div1.sense: to plant trees, Od., Hdt., etc.:—absol., Hes., Xen.:—Mid. to plant for oneself, Pind.

metaph. to beget children, Hes., Hdt., etc.; ὁ φυτεύσας alone, the father, Soph., Eur., etc.; οἱ φυτεύσαντες the parents, Soph.: metaph., ὕβρις φυτεύει τύραννον Soph.:—Pass. to spring from parents, τινος, ἔκ or ἀπό τινος Pind., Soph.
generally, to produce, bring about, cause, κακόν or κακὰ φυτ. Hom.; φυτ. πῆμα Soph.:—Pass., ὄλβος σὺν θεῷ φυτευθείς Soph.
to plant ground with fruit-trees, φυτ. γῆν Thuc.; φυτ. ἀγρόν Xen.:—Pass., γῆ πεφυτευμένη, opp. to ψιλή, Hdt., Dem.

div1.head: φυτικός
div1.sense: of or belonging to plants, τὸ φυτ. the principle of vegetable life, Arist.

div1.head: φύτλη
div1.sense: a stock, generation, Pind., Anth.

div1.head: φυτόν
div1.sense: that which has grown, a plant, tree, Il., Hes., etc.
generally a creature, of men, Eur., Plat.
like ἔρνος, of men, a descendant, child, Eur., Theocr.

div1.head: φυτοσκαφία
div1.sense: gardening, Anth.

div1.head: φυτοσκάφος
div1.sense: digging round plants, φ. ἀνήρ a delver, gardener, Theocr.

div1.head: φυτοσπόρος
div1.sense: planting:—metaph., ὁ φυτ. a father, Soph.

div1.head: φυτός
div1.sense: shaped by nature, without art, Pind.

div1.head: φυτουργός
div1.sense: working at plants; as Subst. a gardener, vinedresser, Anth.
metaph. begetting, Soph., Eur.: the author of a thing, Plat.

div1.head: φυτώνυμος
div1.sense: named from a plant or tree, Anth.

div1.head: φύω
div1.sense: trans., in pres., fut., and aor1 act., to bring forth, produce, put forth leaves, etc., Hom., etc.; so, τρίχας ἔφυσεν made the hair grow, Od.: of a country, φύειν καρπόν τε καὶ ἄνδρας Hdt.

of men, to beget, engender, generate, Lat. procreare, Eur., etc.;— ὁ φύσας the begetter, father (opp. to ὁ φύς, the son, v. infr. B. I. 2), Soph.; and of both parents, οἱ φύσαντες Eur.: metaph., ἥδʼ ἡμέρα φύσει σε will bring to light thy birth, Soph.; χρόνος φύει ἄδηλα Soph.
of persons in regard to themselves, φ. πώγωνα to grow or get a beard, Hdt.; φ. πτερά Ar.: hence the joke in φύειν φράτερας, v. φράτηρ.
metaph., φρένας φύειν to get understanding, Soph.; δόξαν φύειν to form a high opinion of oneself, Hdt.
absol. to put forth shoots, ἀνδρῶν γενεὴ ἡ μὲν φύει ἡ δʼ ἀπολήγει one generation is putting forth scions, the other is ceasing to do so, Il.; δρύες φύοντι Theocr.

Pass., with the intr. tenses of Act., viz. aor2, perf. and plup., to grow, wax, spring up, arise, Od.; φύεται αὐτόματα ῥόδα Hdt.; so, τοῦ κέρα ἐκ κεφαλῆς ἑκκαιδεκάδωρα πεφύκει from his head grew horns sixteen palms long, Il., Plat.; τῶν φύντων αἴτιος the cause of the things produced, Dem.

of men, to be begotten or born, most often in aor2 and perf., ὁ λωφήσων οὐ πέφυκέ πω he that shall abate it is not yet born, Aesch.; μὴ φῦναι νικᾶι not to have been born were best, Soph.:—c. gen., φῦναι or πεφυκέναι τινός to be born or descended from any one, Aesch., etc.; ἀπό τινος Soph., etc.

the perf. and sometimes the aor2 take a pres. sense, to be so and so by nature, πέφυκε κακός, σοφός Trag., etc.; so, οἱ καλῶς πεφυκότες Soph.:—then, simply, to be so and so, ἔφυς μητὴρ θεῶν Aesch.; ἁπλοῦς ὁ μῦθος τῆς ἀληθείας ἔφυ Eur.
c. inf. to be by nature disposed to do so and so, ἔφυν πράσσειν Soph.; φύσει μὴ πεφυκότα τοιαῦτα φωνεῖν not formed by nature so to speak, Soph.; πεφύκασι ἁμαρτάνειν Thuc.
with Preps., φῦναι ἐπὶ δακρύοις to be by nature prone to tears, Eur.; πεφυκὼς πρὸς ἀρετήν Xen.
c. dat. to fall to one by nature, be oneʼs natural lot, πᾶσι θνατοῖς ἔφυ μόρος Soph., etc.
impers., c. inf., it is natural to do, Arist.:—absol., ὡς πέφυκε as is natural, Xen.

div1.head: Φώκαια
div1.sense: a city in Ionia, Hhymn., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Φωκαιεύς
div1.sense: a Phocaean, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: Φωκεύς
div1.sense: a Phocian, Il. (in Epic gen. pl. Φωκήων) , nom. pl. Φωκέες Hdt., Φωκεῖς Thuc., Φωκῆς Soph., gen. Φωκέων Aesch.

div1.head: φώκη
div1.sense: a seal, Od., Hdt.

div1.head: Φωκικός
div1.sense: Phocian, Dem.

div1.head: Φωκίς
div1.sense: (sc. γῆ) , Phocis, on the Corinthian gulf, W. of Boeotia, Xen.; as adj., Phocian, Trag.

div1.head: φωλάς
div1.sense: lurking in a hole, Anth.; of the bear, lying torpid in its cave, Theocr.
full of lurking places, Babr.

div1.head: φωλεός
div1.sense: a hole, den, of lions, Babr.; of foxes, NTest.

div1.head: φωλεύω
div1.sense: to lurk in a hole or den, Theocr., Babr.

div1.head: φωνασκέω
div1.sense: to practise oneʼs voice, learn to sing or declaim, Dem.

div1.head: φωνασκία
div1.sense: practice of the voice, declamation, Dem.

div1.head: φωνασκικός
div1.sense: of or for exercising the voice, φ. ὄργανον a pitch-pipe, Plut.

div1.head: φωνασκός
div1.sense: one who exercises the voice, a singing-master, declaiming-master, Sueton.

div1.head: φωνέω
div1.sense: to produce a sound or tone:

properly of men, to speak loud or clearly, or simply to speak, Hom., etc.;—c. acc. cogn., ὄπα φωνήσασα making the voice sound, Od.; so, βέκος φ. to utter the sound βέκος, Hdt.; so with neut. adj., μέγιστα φωνέειν to have the loudest voice, Hdt.; μέγα φ. Aesch.: —absol. to cry aloud, Soph.; to sing, Theocr.
of animals, to utter their cries, Arist.; of the cock, to crow, NTest.
of a musical instrument, to sound, Eur.; but βροντὴ φ. it has a voice, is significant, Xen.
c. acc. pers. to speak to, call to, Il.; c. dat. to cry to, Ζεῦ ἄνα, σοὶ φωνῶ Soph.
to call by name, call, Soph., NTest.
φ. τινα, c. inf., to command one to do, σὲ φωνῶ μὴ συγκομίζειν Soph.
c. acc. rei, to speak or tell of, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: φωνήεις
div1.sense: uttering a voice or speech, endowed with speech, vocal, Hes., Eur.; βέλη (i. e. ἔπη) φωνᾶντα συνετοῖσι speaking to the wise, Pind.: of animals, endowed with speech, Xen.
of a song, sounding, Pind.
τὰ φωνήεντα (with and without γράμματα) vowels.

div1.head: φώνημα
div1.sense: a sound made, voice, Soph.
a thing spoken, speech, language, Soph.

div1.head: φωνή
div1.sense: a sound, tone, properly the sound of the voice, mostly of men, Lat. vox, Hom., etc.; of a battlecry, Xen.; φωνὴν ῥηγνύναι, Virgilʼs rumpere vocem, to utter an articulate sound, Hdt., Ar.; φ. ἱέναι, Lat. vocem edere, Hdt., etc.: pl. αἱ φ. the tones of the voice, Plat.:—proverb., φωνῇ ὁρᾶν, of a blind man, Soph.
the voice or cry of animals, Od., Hdt., etc.
any articulate sound, as opp. to inarticulate (ψόφος) , Soph., etc.
of sounds from inanimate objects, φ. συρίγγων Eur.; ὀργάνων Plat.
the faculty of speech, discourse, Lat. sermo, Soph.
language, Lat. lingua, Hdt.
a kind of language, dialect, Aesch., Thuc., etc.
a phrase, saying, τὴν Σιμωνίδου φ. Plat.

div1.head: φωνητός
div1.sense: to be spoken, Anth.

div1.head: φωρά
div1.sense: a theft, Bion.

div1.head: φωράω
div1.sense: to search after a thief or theft, search a house, Ar.

in Pass. to be detected, Dem.; with part., κλέπτης ὢν φωρᾶσθαι Dem.; so, κακὸς ὢν ἐφωράθη φίλοις Eur.:—also of things, ἀργύριον ἐφωράθη ἐξαγόμενον money was discovered to be in course of exportation, Xen.

div1.head: φωριαμός
div1.sense: a chest, trunk, coffer, esp. for clothes and linen, Hom.

div1.head: φωρίδιος
div1.sense: stolen, Anth.

div1.head: φώριος
div1.sense: stolen: τὰ φ. stolen goods, Luc.
metaph. secret, clandestine, Theocr.

div1.head: φώρ
div1.sense: a thief, Lat. fur, Hdt., etc.
φωρῶν λιμήν, a harbour near Athens, a little westward of Peiraeeus, used by smugglers, Dem.

div1.head: φώς
div1.etym: used by Poets, just like ἀνήρ
div1.sense: a man, Hom., Trag.
a man, as opp. to a woman, Od., Soph.; δύʼ οἰκτρὼ φῶτε, of a man and his wife, Eur.
a man, opp. to a god, Il., Aesch.

div1.head: φωστήρ
div1.sense: that which gives light, an illuminator, Anth.:— οἱ φωστῆρες the lights of heaven, stars, Anth., NTest.

div1.head: φωσφόρος
div1.sense: bringing or giving light, Eur., Ar.:—as Subst., ὁ φωσφόρος (sc. ἀστήρ) , the lightbringer, Lat. Lucifer, i. e. the morning-star, a name specially given to the planet Venus, Cic.
of the eye, Eur., Plat.
torch-bearing, epith. of certain deities, esp. of Hecate, Eur.

div1.head: φωταγωγός
div1.sense: guiding with a light: φωταγωγός (sc. θύρα) , an opening for light, a window, Luc.

div1.head: φωτεινός
div1.sense: shining, bright, Xen.

div1.head: φωτίζω
div1.sense: to enlighten, illuminate: to instruct, teach, NTest.
to bring to light, publish, NTest.
to enlighten spiritually, and then to baptize, NTest.

div1.head: φωτισμός
div1.sense: illumination, light, NTest.
